The rain in Barrow-in-Furness had a texture. Not just wet, but greasy, carrying the salt of the Irish Sea and the metallic tang of the shipyard on every drop. It coated the slate roofs of the terraced houses on Salthouse Road until they shone like polished jet, and it slicked the pavements with a treacherous sheen. Alfie Blackwood pulled the collar of his worn peacoat tighter, the coarse wool scratching at his neck. He hated this kind of weather. It got into the bones, a damp chill that no amount of tea or cheap whisky could fully exorcise. More than that, it warped the echoes. Water was a smudger, a great blurrer of residual energies, turning sharp memories into watercolour bleeds.

He stopped opposite the cordon. Two police cars were parked haphazardly, their blue lights painting silent, strobing patterns on the grim-faced brickwork of the tenement block. A small crowd of onlookers huddled under umbrellas, their faces pale and curious in the gloom of the late afternoon. Alfie ignored them. He wasn't here for the spectacle. He was here because Detective Inspector Morrison had called, and when Morrison called, it was never for a chat about the Bluebirds’ latest dismal performance.

Morrison was waiting for him just inside the tape, a hulking figure in a rumpled suit that looked like it had been slept in. And knowing Morrison, it probably had. His face was a roadmap of exhaustion, deep-set lines carved around his eyes and mouth. He held a steaming styrofoam cup that did little to warm his expression.

“Alfie. Thanks for coming.” His voice was a low rumble, thick with a Furness accent that had been weathered by decades of cigarettes and bad news. “It’s a rum one.”

“They always are, Dave,” Alfie said, ducking under the tape. “You don’t call me for the simple stuff.”

“Nowt simple about this.” Morrison gestured with his head towards the building's entrance. “Third floor. Flat 3B. Name’s Kevin Tiller. A fitter from the yard. Lived alone.”

“Lived?”

“Aye. He’s not living anymore.”

The communal stairwell stank of stale cabbage and damp. The lino was cracked, the wallpaper peeling in long, jaundiced strips. Alfie’s boots made soft, squelching sounds on the worn steps. He could feel the building’s history pressing in on him, a century of minor miseries and fleeting joys soaked into the very plaster. It was a low, constant hum, the background noise of his life. Most people felt it as a vague sense of unease or nostalgia. For Alfie, it was like listening to a thousand quiet conversations at once. He’d learned to tune it out, to turn the volume down until it was just a faint static at the edge of his senses.

The door to 3B was ajar, a uniformed constable standing beside it with a carefully blank expression. Inside, the flat was small and surprisingly tidy. A threadbare sofa, a television, a shelf of naval history books. But the orderliness of the living room only made the chaos in the small workshop beyond it more jarring.

Kevin Tiller was on the floor, amidst a scatter of metal shavings and specialised tools. He was on his back, eyes wide and staring at the ceiling, a single, dark hole in the centre of his forehead. There was no blood. None. The edges of the wound were cauterised, blackened and seared into the skin.

“Forensics are stumped,” Morrison muttered, staying by the doorway. “No entry wound at the back. No projectile. No scorch marks on anything else in the room. Just… that.”

Alfie didn't answer. He was already scanning the room, his eyes not just seeing but *feeling*. The air was thick with a residue, a sharp, cold spike of power that felt utterly alien. It was like a perfectly cut sliver of ice jammed into the warm, messy hum of the building. Purposeful. Precise. And utterly without passion. He walked slowly around the body, careful not to touch anything. His gaze fell on the workbench. It was covered in intricate metal sculptures, small, beautiful things crafted from scrap. Birds with bolt-heads for eyes, ships with hulls of beaten copper pipe. Kevin Tiller had been an artist.

And then he saw it. Lying beside Tiller’s outstretched hand was a single, heavy-duty rivet, the kind used to plate the submarines built in the Devonshire Dock Hall. It looked ordinary. Unremarkable. But to Alfie’s senses, it was screaming.

“The rivet,” Alfie said, his voice quiet. “That’s it.”

Morrison frowned. “The lads have bagged everything else. That was just lying there. Probably dropped it.”

“He didn’t drop it.” Alfie knelt, his knees cracking. He pulled a thin leather glove from his coat pocket and carefully picked up the rivet. Even through the leather, the chill was intense. A soul-deep cold that had nothing to do with temperature. It felt… hungry. He held it for a moment, then looked at Morrison. “I need to be alone with this, Dave. And I need somewhere quiet. No electrics. No chatter.”

Morrison’s expression was a mixture of scepticism and resignation. He’d seen Alfie work before, but he’d never understood it. He didn’t need to. He just needed the results. “The old morgue at the station. It’s just a storage cellar now. Will that do?”

“Perfect,” Alfie said, his eyes fixed on the metal object in his gloved hand. “It’ll do just reet.”

The cellar was cold, musty, and blessedly silent. A single, bare bulb hung from the ceiling, but Alfie had Morrison kill the power. He preferred the dark. It made the other things easier to see. He placed the rivet on a cold, slate slab that had once held bodies and now held dusty archive boxes. He took off his glove. The air was still. So still.

He was a warlock. A ridiculous word for a ridiculous job. It conjured images of pointy hats and bubbling cauldrons, not a bloke in a peacoat from Barrow who could read the stories left on old metal. His was a grubby, industrial sort of magic, born of the iron and steel that had defined his hometown for generations. He didn't cast spells; he coaxed secrets. He didn't scry in crystal balls; he saw history in a rust stain.

Taking a deep, steadying breath, he pressed his bare thumb against the cold, smooth head of the rivet.

And the world fractured.

It wasn't a vision, not a film played behind his eyes. It was a plunge. He was the rivet. He was cold steel, forged in fire and pressure, waiting in a dusty bin. Then a hand—Tiller’s hand, calloused and strong—plucked him out. The scent of oil and sweat. The feel of the man’s workbench, the vibration of a file against a neighbouring piece of scrap. He felt Tiller’s frustration, the creative block he was fighting. He wanted to build something new, something different.

Then the air in the workshop changed. The low hum of the television in the next room vanished, replaced by an absolute, crushing silence. A new presence. Cold. Arrogant. Alfie felt it through Tiller’s skin, a prickling on the back of his neck. Tiller turned. A figure stood in the doorway. Tall, silhouetted against the light from the hall. Alfie couldn’t see a face, just a shape. A long coat. A sense of stillness that was more menacing than any sudden movement.

The figure raised a hand. There was no incantation, no word spoken. Just a gathering of… nothing. A point of absolute cold and shadow coalesced in the air between them. Tiller, holding the rivet, took an instinctive step back, his heart hammering a frantic rhythm that vibrated through the metal in his hand.

The point of shadow shot forward. It wasn't a projectile; it was a puncture in reality. It moved without sound, without disturbing the air. It struck Tiller in the forehead.

And through the rivet, Alfie felt the man’s life unravel. Not just stop. Unravel. Memories, sensations, emotions—all pulled, thread by thread, from his body, drawn into the impossible cold of the wound. It was an obliteration. A consumption. Alfie felt Tiller’s last thought, not of fear, but of confusion. A simple, heartbreaking *Why?*

The life force, a torrent of energy, was sucked into the void. But not all of it. A tiny, stray spark, a flicker of Tiller’s dying essence, lashed out in its death throe. It didn't strike the attacker. It struck the nearest, most conductive object. The rivet in his hand.

The vision ended. Alfie snatched his thumb back as if burned, stumbling away from the slate slab. He was gasping, sweat beading on his forehead despite the cellar's chill. The echo wasn't just a memory of the event; it was the event itself, imprinted on the metal, and with it, a sliver of Kevin Tiller’s stolen soul. That was the source of the unnatural cold. The rivet was a tiny lich-object, a phylactery by accident.

But that wasn't what shook Alfie to his core. It was the magic. The precise, silent, soul-devouring cold. He had felt it once before, years ago. A rumour. A whisper in the hidden corners of the world he inhabited. A style of magic, a philosophy of power that treated life not as sacred, but as fuel. They called it the Umbral Hand. A nihilistic cabal that believed in power through erasure.

And as the last fragments of the vision faded from his mind, one final image burned itself into his memory. Just for a second, as the killer lowered his hand, a sign had shimmered in the air where the magic had been woven. Not a physical light, but a sigil of pure absence, a mark that drank the light around it. A spiralling serpent, endlessly consuming its own tail, but with a shard of obsidian at its centre.

Malachi’s sigil.

Alfie’s breath hitched. No. It couldn't be. Malachi was a ghost story, a bogeyman that elder warlocks used to scare apprentices. A cautionary tale about ambition and the pursuit of power for its own sake. A prodigy who had vanished from the circles decades ago, presumed dead or driven mad by his own dark arts.

But that sigil was unmistakable. And it was here. In Barrow-in-Furness. In a tidy little flat, murdering a man who made sculptures out of scrap metal. It made no sense. None of it.

He leaned against the cold brick wall, the damp seeping into his coat. He could still feel the echo of Tiller’s final, confused thought. *Why?*

It was a good question. A question that was going to get him into a world of trouble. Because Malachi, ghost story or not, had just made it personal. He’d left a calling card. And Alfie Blackwood was the only one in this salt-sprayed, forgotten corner of the country who knew how to read it. A cold dread, far deeper than the cellar's chill, began to settle in his stomach. This wasn't just a murder. This was a message. This was the beginning of something.He pushed himself off the wall, his joints protesting. The cellar suddenly felt less like a sanctuary and more like a tomb. The rivet on the slab no longer seemed like a simple piece of metal; it was a gravestone, a tiny, cold monument to a stolen life. He couldn't leave it here. It was evidence, yes, but not for Morrison's world. It was a piece of Tiller, a fragment of a soul trapped in steel, and leaving it in a police evidence bag felt like a final, unforgivable violation. With his gloved hand, he picked it up and slipped it deep into his peacoat pocket, where it rested against his hip like a cold stone.

He climbed the stairs, emerging from the quiet dark into the harsh fluorescent buzz of the station's back corridor. The transition was jarring. Here, the world was mundane, brightly lit, and smelled of cheap floor polish and lukewarm coffee. Morrison was leaning against a filing cabinet, talking to the uniformed constable who had been at the flat. He looked up as Alfie approached, his brow furrowed with impatient hope.

“Well?” Morrison’s voice was a gravelly demand. “Did your… thing… give you anything? Or have you just been communing with the dust bunnies?”

Alfie paused, choosing his words as carefully as he would pick his way through a room full of unstable enchantments. He couldn't tell the truth. The truth involved soul-eating sorcery and a bogeyman from a hidden world. The truth would get him a padded cell, not a case file. He had to translate the impossible into the merely improbable.

“It’s not a gun, Dave. Not in any way we’d understand it,” Alfie began, his voice low and even. “There was no bullet. The wound… it’s like a puncture, but made of energy. Something that burns and freezes at the same time. It’s highly focused. Almost surgical.”

Morrison scowled, rubbing a hand over his tired face. “Energy? What are you talking about? Like a laser?”

“No. A laser would have burned the whole room. This was contained. Precise. It didn't just kill him; it did something *to* him. It took something. Think of it less like a firearm and more like… a specialised industrial tool. Something experimental. Maybe military. Something that isn’t supposed to exist outside of a black-ops lab.” He hated the lie, hated the theatre of it, but it was a necessary bridge between his world and Morrison’s. It pointed towards secrecy, advanced technology, and ruthless perpetrators—all things a detective could understand and investigate.

Morrison absorbed this, his policeman’s mind sifting it for workable angles. “Experimental tech? Here? In Barrow? Who was this Tiller bloke to get hit with something like that? He was a fitter. He liked history books and made little metal birds.”

“I don’t know,” Alfie admitted, and that part was entirely true. “Maybe he saw something at the shipyard he shouldn't have. Maybe he stumbled into something. The motive is a blank. But the killer… they’re professional. Quiet. They left nothing behind. No physical trace. They wanted to be a ghost.”

“They left the body,” Morrison grumbled.

“They left a statement,” Alfie corrected softly. “This wasn’t about killing Kevin Tiller. It was about *how* he was killed.” He tapped his coat pocket, where the rivet lay cold and heavy. “That rivet you were going to bag. I need to hold onto it.”

Morrison’s eyes narrowed. “Evidence, Alfie. I can’t just let you walk out with it.”

“What’s it evidence of? A man dropping a rivet in his own workshop?” Alfie met his gaze. “To your forensics, it’s a lump of scrap metal. Let me have it. Let me see what else it can tell me. You’re chasing a ghost with no prints, no weapon, and no motive. Your labs will find nothing. You know they won’t. This is your only lead, Dave, even if you don't understand it.”

The detective stood there for a long moment, the hum of the lights filling the silence between them. He was a man of procedure, of tangible facts and witness statements. Alfie was his wild card, his trip into the twilight zone that he tolerated only because, more than once, it had yielded a result he couldn't have gotten any other way. With a sigh that seemed to draw up all the exhaustion in the world, he gave a curt, reluctant nod.

“Fine. But you call me. You find out what a ‘fitter from the yard’ was doing to get zapped by a sci-fi ray gun, and you call me the second you do. I don’t want to read about it in some UFO-spotter’s newsletter first.”

“You’ll be my first call,” Alfie promised. Another small lie. His first call, if he made one at all, would be to someone who understood what a spiralling serpent with a shard of obsidian at its heart truly meant. And he dreaded making that call more than anything.

He turned and walked away, not waiting for a dismissal. He pushed through the station doors and back out into the greasy Barrow evening. The rain had eased to a persistent, clinging drizzle. It wasn’t a smudger of echoes anymore; it felt like a shroud, muffling the town in a blanket of damp misery. The streetlights cast long, distorted reflections on the wet pavement, turning the familiar road into something alien and unwelcoming.

He pulled his collar tight again, but the chill he felt now had nothing to do with the weather. Malachi. Here. Why? The question beat in his mind like a second heart. It couldn't be a coincidence. Warlocks of Malachi's calibre didn't do things by accident. Every move was a sentence in a larger statement. Murdering a seemingly insignificant man in a forgotten corner of the country wasn’t a random act of violence. It was the first line of a new chapter. And Alfie Blackwood, reader of metal and rust, was terrified he was the only one in the city who had been given the book.## Chapter 2

Alfie’s flat was on a side street off Abbey Road, a top-floor conversion in a solid old Victorian house that had once belonged to a ship's captain. The walk there was a familiar litany of cracked paving stones and the faint, ever-present scent of fried food from a distant takeaway. Tonight, though, every shadow seemed to stretch a little too far, and the sound of his own footsteps seemed unnervingly loud in the damp quiet. The rivet was a point of absolute cold in his pocket, a psychic deadweight that made his hip ache. He carried it like a disease, a secret that separated him from the oblivious, rain-soaked figures he passed on the street. They were worried about bills, about the football scores, about getting home to a hot meal. He was worried about a sorcerer who ate souls.

His home was his sanctuary, a meticulously controlled environment. There were no smart speakers, no wifi router blinking in the corner. The only technology was a twenty-year-old television that was rarely switched on and a sturdy landline telephone. The rest of the space was filled with books and metal. Not the screaming, imprinted metal of the outside world, but quiet things he had found and patiently ‘cleansed’ over the years: old engine parts, Victorian ironmongery, lumps of raw haematite from the Cumbrian fells. They filled the shelves and lined the mantelpiece, each one a silent, grounding presence. He had curated his silence, building a fortress not of brick, but of sensory nullity. It was the only way he could ever feel truly alone and at peace.

He didn't dare leave the rivet out on a surface. It was more than an object; it was a wound in the fabric of the room, its unnatural chill a constant, weeping reminder of the murder. From a heavy oak chest in the corner, he retrieved a small, lead-lined box, the kind once used for transporting photographic plates. He had a few of them, reserved for objects too loud, too violent, to be left exposed. Placing the gloved rivet inside and closing the heavy lid felt like shutting a coffin. The oppressive cold in the room lessened immediately, but he could still feel it, a faint, insistent thrum of stolen life locked in the dark. It pulsed like a migraine behind his eyes, a sliver of Kevin Tiller’s final, terrified moments, now a permanent part of his quiet space.

He stood in the centre of his living room for a long time, the low hum of the streetlights outside the only sound. He couldn't do this alone. The lie to Morrison had bought him time, but it was a flimsy shield against the truth of the matter. Malachi’s sigil wasn’t a challenge; it was a declaration. It was an announcement that the rules had changed, and that the old ghost stories were stepping out of the shadows. The thought made his hands feel cold and clumsy. He ran a hand through his damp hair, his gaze falling on the old black rotary phone on his sideboard. There was only one person he could call. One person who might have an inkling of the scale of this, who dealt not in whispers and rust, but in the lore and law of their hidden world. Elara Vance. The name tasted like dust and regret. She had been his mentor, of a sort, decades ago, the Keeper of the Athenaeum of the Unseen, a grand title for a woman who ran a secret, crumbling library of forbidden knowledge from a basement in Manchester. He had walked away from that world, from its rigid hierarchies and its dangerous politics, preferring the solitary grime of Barrow. To call her now was to admit defeat. It was to confess that his small, quiet life was no longer enough to protect him.

With a heavy sense of inevitability, he walked to the sideboard, lifted the heavy bakelite receiver, and dialled the number from memory. It rang four times, each buzz echoing the frantic hammering in his chest. He was about to hang up when the line clicked open. There was no greeting, just an expectant silence.
“Elara,” he said, his voice hoarse.
“Blackwood.” Her voice was exactly as he remembered: dry as old parchment and sharp enough to cut glass. “To what do I owe the disruption? Have you finally rusted shut in that dreadful northern port you call a home?”
“I need some information,” he said, ignoring the jibe. “A murder. Here. In Barrow.”
“I’m not a policewoman. And you, if I recall, are no longer a part of any organisation that would concern itself with such matters. You made your choice to become a provincial antiquarian of scrap.”
“The method, Elara,” Alfie cut in, his patience fraying. “It was cold. Precise. It unravelled the victim. No passion, just… consumption.” He paused, forcing the next words out. “He left a sigil. A serpent eating its own tail, with a shard of obsidian at the centre.”
The silence on the other end of the line was suddenly different. The dismissive, academic quiet was replaced by something sharp and absolute, like an indrawn breath. When she finally spoke, all trace of arid wit was gone, replaced by a cold, deadly seriousness. “Where did you see this, Alfie?”
“In the echo. On the murder weapon.”
“Malachi,” she whispered, and the name itself felt like a drop in temperature over the phone line. “The sigil of the Umbral Hand. You fool. You absolute fool. That wasn’t a calling card left for the police. It was a baited hook. It was left for anyone like you who came sniffing around. By reading it, you’ve announced yourself. You’ve rung his dinner bell.”

A cold dread, far worse than the rivet’s chill, washed over Alfie. He had thought he was the reader, the observer. He had never considered that he was the one being read. “Bogeyman,” he muttered, more to himself than to her. “Everyone said he was just a story.”
“He was a cautionary tale that everyone hoped was a myth,” Elara snapped. “He founded the Hand on the principle that life, that a soul, is just a resource to be harvested. He vanished forty years ago because the old guard hunted him to the brink of extinction. We all assumed he was dead. We were wrong. He was rebuilding. Growing stronger in the dark. He does not act without purpose, Alfie. The victim, this Tiller, is irrelevant. Malachi was after something Tiller had, or something he knew. And now, he will be after what *you* know. You must get rid of the object you read. Destroy it.”
“I can’t,” Alfie said, his hand tightening on the receiver. “There’s a piece of the victim’s soul trapped in it. An echo of his life.”
There was a sigh, a weary, ancient sound. “Then you are in more trouble than I can possibly convey over a telephone line. Find out what Tiller had. Find out what Malachi wants. Find it before he finds you. And Alfie… don’t call this number again. It’s a liability I can no longer afford.” The line went dead, leaving Alfie in the oppressive silence of his flat, the dial tone a shrill, mocking lament.

He was marked. A target. The quiet life he had built for himself was over. Panic was a rising tide, but he forced it down. Panic was a luxury. He needed more than the memory of a murder; he needed a reason. He needed to know what had brought this nightmare to Kevin Tiller’s door. He walked back to the lead-lined box and opened it. The rivet lay inside, inert and cold. To touch it again, to deliberately plunge back into that violation, felt like an act of self-mutilation. But Elara was right. It was his only path forward. He took the rivet out with his bare hand this time, the cold searing his palm, and walked to the centre of the room. He closed his eyes, took a deep, ragged breath, and focused not on the sharp spike of the murder, but on the fainter, warmer hum beneath it. He pushed past the screaming echo of death, searching for the quiet whisper of life that had come before.

The plunge was disorienting, a chaotic swirl of fragmented images. Not a film, but a box of old photographs thrown in the air. The tang of welding fumes. The heft of a hammer. The satisfaction of a perfectly flush joint. The grey, churning expanse of the Irish Sea seen from the top of the Devonshire Dock Hall. Then, a memory sharpened, crystallising out of the blur. It was Tiller, but younger. He wasn’t in the main yard. He was on a smaller, grittier job, part of a crew contracted for demolition at the old VSEL works on the far side of Walney Island, a place that had been left to rot for decades. They were breaking up an old, concrete-and-steel submarine pen, one that hadn't been used since the fifties. The memory was thick with the smell of rust and salt and decay. Tiller was guiding a crane operator, clearing a collapsed section of the sea wall, when they found it. A dark shape, wedged deep in the foundations. It was a piece of wreckage, gnarled and ancient, covered in layers of marine growth. But as the crane tore it loose, a section broke off. It wasn't rusted metal. It was something else. A material as black as coal, but with a strange, non-reflective surface that seemed to drink the weak sunlight. It felt dense, heavy in Tiller's memory-hand, and weirdly inert. To Tiller, the artist, it was a fascinating new medium. To Alfie, feeling it through the echo, it was terrifying. It had no story. It was psychically blank, a void in a world where everything had a history. Tiller, fascinated and breaking every rule in the book, pocketed a small, fist-sized shard of the strange, black material before the foreman could see.

The vision shattered, dumping Alfie back onto his own two feet in the middle of his living room. He was shivering violently, the rivet now feeling almost hot in his palm. He dropped it as if it were a burning coal. He knew. He knew what Malachi was after. It wasn't Kevin Tiller, the gentle sculptor of scrap. It was Tiller the magpie, the man who had found a piece of something that shouldn't exist and taken it home. The murder was nothing more than a brutal acquisition. A new question, colder and sharper than any that had come before, lodged itself in Alfie’s brain. What in God's name was this silent, history-less black material, and what could a warlock who fed on the very essence of life want with something that had none? He was no longer just solving a murder. He was standing between a predator of unimaginable power and a prize he couldn't begin to comprehend. The hunt was on, and Alfie Blackwood was now officially the prey.The rivet clattered on the floorboards, a jarring, metallic sound in the profound stillness of the room. Alfie stared at it, his hand throbbing not with heat or cold, but with a deep, aching emptiness where the vision had been. The memory of the black, history-less material was a void in his mind, an impossible contradiction to the fundamental laws of his world. Everything had a story. A cracked teacup held the echo of a thousand morning arguments; a rusted nail held the memory of the hammer’s blow and the carpenter’s sweat. But this material Tiller had found was a cipher, a page torn from the book of existence before any words could be written on it.

He understood now. Malachi, the ultimate consumer, who fed on the rich tapestry of life and memory, had found its antithesis. An object of pure absence. What would he want with it? To study it? To destroy it? Or to somehow weaponise that nothingness? The question was a black hole in itself, pulling all other thoughts into its orbit. The horror of Tiller’s death was now eclipsed by the terrifying implications of its motive. This was bigger than a single murder in a backwater town. This was about a fundamental principle of power.

Panic was a physical thing, a tightening in his chest, a frantic fluttering in his gut. His sanctuary, this flat he had so carefully insulated from the world’s psychic noise, now felt like a cage. Malachi’s sigil was a brand on his mind's eye, and Elara’s warning was a death knell. *You’ve rung his dinner bell.* He couldn’t stay here. The hunter was coming, and Alfie had just pinpointed the location of the treasure map. He had to get to the shard first. It was the only card he had to play, the only piece of leverage in a game where his own soul was the ante.

The workshop. It had to be there. Tiller the artist would have kept his most fascinating, most unusual find close to his other materials. But the flat was a crime scene, sealed and guarded. He couldn't go to Morrison. The bridge of lies he’d built between their worlds was too fragile to bear the weight of a request to re-enter an active murder investigation based on a psychic hunch. There was only one way. He had to go back to Salthouse Road and break in. The thought felt reckless, suicidal even, but staying put felt like a slower, more certain death.

He forced himself to move, his actions deliberate and methodical, a bulwark against the rising fear. He put the rivet back in its lead-lined box and slid the box into his deep peacoat pocket. It was his compass, his connection to Tiller's last moments, and a terrible burden. From under his bed, he pulled a small, worn leather roll containing a set of old locksmith's tools, the metal gleaming dully. They were relics of a misspent youth, skills he hadn't needed for twenty years, but like everything in his life, he had kept them. You never knew when the past might become useful. He pulled on a dark woollen hat and a pair of thin leather gloves, his reflection in the hall mirror a grim, shadowy figure he barely recognised. The warlock of rust and echoes was about to become a common burglar.

The streets of Barrow were emptier now, the rain having driven most people indoors. The night air was thick and cold, each breath a damp shock to the lungs. Every flicker of a curtain in a window, every car that swept its headlights down the street, felt like a threat. Paranoia was a new and unwelcome companion, whispering at the edge of his senses. He felt exposed, his every step a drumbeat announcing his position to the unseen hunter. He kept to the back alleys and unlit ginnels, his path a dark mirror of the town’s official geography, a route known only to cats, foxes, and men with things to hide.

Salthouse Road was quiet. The police cars were gone, but the blue and white tape still stretched across the tenement's entrance, a flimsy, plastic ghost of the earlier drama. A single streetlamp cast a sickly orange glow over the wet brick, making the building look even more haggard and grim. There was no uniformed officer on watch. Morrison was running a stretched-thin force, and with no obvious suspect, a static guard on a sealed flat was a luxury they couldn't afford overnight. Alfie slipped into the shadows of the alley that ran alongside the building, his heart pounding against his ribs. The air here was thick with the stink of overflowing bins and stale beer. He looked up. Third floor. Tiller’s window was dark. He found the drainpipe, a sturdy, cast-iron relic of Victorian plumbing. It was slick with greasy rain, but the brackets were solid. With a grunt, he began to climb, the coarse metal cold and unforgiving under his gloved hands.

The window to the flat’s small bathroom was cracked, held together with yellowing tape. It was a flimsy defence. Using the butt of a heavy tension wrench, he gave the corner a sharp, carefully muffled rap. The glass fractured with a dull crunch. He picked out the broken shards, creating a hole big enough to snake his arm through and unlatch the simple catch. He slid the window open and hoisted himself inside, landing with a soft thud on the worn lino. The flat was cold and silent, but it was a different silence from before. It was the sterile, violated silence of a place that had been picked over by strangers. A fine layer of black fingerprint dust coated the doorframes and light switches. Small plastic evidence markers dotted the floor of the living room.

He moved silently towards the workshop, his senses on high alert. The psychic residue of the murder was still there, a sharp, cold spike, but it was overlaid now with the echoes of the forensics team—their professional detachment, their muttered conversations, their faint, lingering scent of latex and coffee. He stepped into the workshop and his breath caught. The place had been turned upside-down. Tools were laid out in neat rows for photographing, Tiller’s beautiful, half-finished metal sculptures now sat in numbered evidence bags.
