He sat heavily on the edge of the hard bed, the cold, lead-lined weight of the shard pouch a constant, pressing reminder against his chest. His first day in his new life was over, and all it had cost him was everything.He sat on the edge of the hard bed for a time that had no measure, the only sound the whisper of the ventilation system, a sterile breath that was the polar opposite of the salt-laced wind he had known his entire life. The data slate lay dark beside him, his own death certificate contained in its memory. He was a ghost, but not a restless one. He was simply… erased. The thought should have been terrifying, but he was too profoundly weary for terror. It was just a fact, as solid and unchangeable as the white walls of his cell. He reached for the food tray, his movements slow and automatic. He peeled back the plastic film. Inside was a grey, protein paste, a portion of steamed, unnaturally green vegetables, and a dense, biscuit-like rectangle of carbohydrates. It smelled of nothing. He took a bite of the paste. It tasted of nutrients, of sustenance, of utter, soul-crushing absence. It was the perfect meal for his new life. He ate mechanically, not because he was hungry, but because his body was a machine that required fuel, and he was its reluctant operator.

When he had finished, he pushed the tray aside and drew his knees up to his chest, wrapping his arms around them. The lead-lined pouch containing the shard was a cold, heavy weight against his sternum. In the profound silence of the room, a silence that was a sensory void, the shard’s own perfect nullity felt almost companionable. It was the one thing in this place that was honest. The walls pretended to be solid, the food pretended to be sustenance, the Directorate pretended to be offering him a life. The shard made no such pretences. It was a hole, and it did not apologize for it. He found a strange solace in its integrity. It was the only landmark he had left in a world that had been wiped clean of all distinguishing features. He was no longer Alfie Blackwood, the warlock of Barrow. He was the man with the hole in his chest, a custodian of nothing.

The hiss of the door sliding open broke his reverie. Kaelen stood in the doorway, holding a data slate of her own. She did not enter fully but stood on the threshold, a clear demarcation between her space and his. Her grey eyes swept over the room, noting the empty food tray, his posture, the dark slate on the desk. She was a scientist observing a specimen in its new, controlled habitat. She registered his compliance, his consumption of the provided nutrients, and filed it away as a data point.

“Your bio-signs are stabilizing,” she announced, her voice as flat and devoid of texture as the food he had just eaten. “The preliminary evaluation yielded some… anomalous readings. Your ability to influence ferrous materials without a significant expenditure of energy is a deviation from known psychometric models. The effect on the servo was not a kinetic push. It was more akin to a semantic suggestion. You told it what it was, and it listened. This is new.”

“I’m full of surprises,” Alfie mumbled, his voice a dry rasp. He did not look at her, keeping his gaze fixed on the opposite white wall.

“That is why you are valuable,” she replied, ignoring his sarcasm. “And as our newest, and most… unique consultant, your first consultation is now required. Your cooperation in Lab Three, while grudging, confirmed your utility. Now it is time to apply it.” She tapped her data slate, and the screen on his desk lit up, displaying a rotating, three-dimensional image of a new object. It was a twisted knot of metal, about the size of a human heart. It was clearly not man-made. The metal was a dark, iridescent bronze, and it was fused in places with a crystalline material that pulsed with a faint, sickly purple light. It looked diseased, a piece of biomechanical viscera ripped from some impossible creature.

“Item 734,” Kaelen stated. “Recovered from a downed satellite over the Siberian tundra three years ago. It emits a low-level psychic broadcast on a repeating loop. The content of the broadcast induces paranoia, obsessive-compulsive behaviour, and eventually, catatonic schizophrenia in all sentient life within a ten-meter radius. All attempts to read its origin or purpose via conventional psychic or technological means have failed. The broadcast is a psychic signal, but it has no recognizable author or emotional content. It is a signal without a story. We have shielded it, of course, but we have never understood it. You, Mr. Blackwood, are a new variable. You read stories where others cannot. We want to know what story this object is telling.”

Alfie finally looked at her, a cold dread seeping into the marrow of his bones. This was his new job. Not to find lost things or coax secrets from old iron, but to be the Directorate’s canary, sent down the darkest, most poisonous mines of reality to see if he would sing or die. This was not a consultation; it was a vivisection. They would expose him to these horrors, these broken pieces of other worlds, and record how he broke. He thought of Kevin Tiller, dead on his workshop floor, his final thought a simple, heartbreaking *Why?* Alfie was beginning to understand that in this new world, ‘why’ was a luxury, a question that had been replaced by a much simpler one: ‘what?’

“And if I say no?” he asked, his voice quiet.

“Then you will remain in this room, and we will continue with less… collaborative forms of evaluation,” Kaelen replied, the threat delivered with the detached calm of a doctor prescribing an unpleasant but necessary treatment. “Your status as a consultant is contingent upon you consulting. The choice, as always, is yours.” She turned to leave. “Lab Three. In five minutes.”

The door hissed shut, leaving him once more in the profound, deadening silence. He looked at the image of the pulsating, diseased object on the screen. It was an invitation to madness, a doorway to a new kind of horror. But it was also a door out of this white room. He pushed himself off the bed. He was no longer the quiet reader of Barrow’s history. He was an asset, a tool. And a tool, he thought with a grim finality, was meant to be used. He would go to their lab. He would touch their monster. He would read its terrible story. But he would read it for himself, another secret to be held close, another piece of leverage in the long, quiet war he was now fighting for the tattered remnants of his own soul.### Chapter 10

The five minutes passed in a silence so profound it felt like a countdown to an execution. The door to his cell slid open with a soft hiss, and Elias stood there, his presence as solid and unyielding as a block of granite. He didn’t speak, merely jerked his head in a silent command. Alfie rose from the bed, his body stiff, and followed the silent guard down the sterile white corridor. This walk felt different from the last. The initial shock had worn off, replaced by a grim, cold resolve. He was a tool being taken from its box. He could resent the hand that held him, or he could learn its shape, its grip, its weaknesses. He chose the latter. The Directorate thought they were in control, but a tool has a purpose of its own; a hammer is only a hammer until you decide to use it as a lockpick.

Lab Three had been reconfigured. The invasive chair with its articulated arms was gone, retracted into the walls like a predator’s claws. In its place, a slender, black metal pedestal rose from the centre of the floor. Upon it, resting under a shimmering, faintly visible containment field, was Item 734. Seeing it in person was far more unsettling than the image on the slate. The bronze-like metal seemed to shift in colour from brown to a sickly green, and the crystalline structures embedded within it pulsed with a slow, languid rhythm, like a diseased heart. Even with the containment field in place, Alfie could feel its presence. It was a psychic drone, a low, monotonous frequency that seemed to vibrate at the very edge of hearing, promising to unpick the seams of a sane mind. The air in the room felt thick, heavy with the object's sheer wrongness.

“The protocol is straightforward,” Kaelen’s disembodied voice announced from the hidden speakers. “We will lower the containment field to five percent integrity. This will allow for physical contact while mitigating the full psycho-degenerative broadcast. You will approach the item, place your hand upon it, and read what you can. Your vital signs, neural activity, and psychic emissions will be monitored in real-time. Do not maintain contact for more than fifteen seconds on your first attempt. The degenerative effects are cumulative. We do not wish to damage our new consultant on his first day.” The final sentence was delivered with the dry, detached air of a factory manager concerned about a valuable piece of equipment.

Alfie approached the pedestal, the humming drone growing stronger with every step. It was not a chaotic noise like the shipyard had been; it was a single, pure, monotonous note of wrongness. He could feel it trying to find purchase in his mind, searching for loose threads of memory or emotion to pull. His old method of passive listening would be suicide here; it would be like opening his front door in the middle of a hurricane. He needed a new defence. He reached for the memory of the null-shard, not its power, but its nature. The feeling of absolute, perfect silence. The absence of story. He focused, building a small, conceptual shield of that perfect nothingness around his mind, a pocket of personal silence in the face of the maddening drone. It was a new and clumsy technique, a psychic gambit, but it was all he had.

“Containment field at five percent,” Kaelen’s voice announced. The shimmer around the object visibly thinned. Alfie took a deep breath, extended his hand, and pressed his palm against the cold, strangely greasy surface of Item 734. The universe fractured. It was not a vision, not a story, not an echo. It was a data-stream, a torrent of pure, weaponized information forced directly into his consciousness. He saw no images, but he perceived blueprints. He heard no sounds, but he understood schematics. The pulsing purple light was a carrier wave for a viral code, a set of instructions designed to break down and rewrite not just organic matter, but the fundamental physics of reality itself. It was a terraforming engine, a self-replicating cancer that saw a universe of rock, water, and life as nothing more than raw material for its own expansion. The drone he had heard was not a broadcast; it was the sound of the universe screaming as it was being fed into a grinder. He felt the entity behind it, but it was not a mind. It was a blind, relentless, biological imperative, as mindless and as purposeful as a plague.

With a choked gasp, he tore his hand away. The connection snapped, but not cleanly. He stumbled back, a searing pain lancing through his skull as if a hot needle had been plunged into his brain. He raised a trembling hand to his face and felt the warm, wet track of blood pouring from his nose. But the physical pain was nothing compared to the psychic debris left behind. The alien data-stream had left a residue, a ghost in his machine. In a quiet, cordoned-off corner of his mind, a string of impossible, glowing purple geometry now flickered, a fragment of the viral code he had downloaded, now lodged in his own soul. He had touched the monster, and a piece of it had followed him home.

“Report, consultant!” Kaelen’s voice was sharp, demanding, cutting through the haze of pain. “What is the nature of the broadcast?” Alfie sagged against the wall, wiping the blood on the sleeve of his grey jumpsuit. He fought to get his breathing under control, his mind racing. He could not tell them the truth. A reality-rewriting virus? They would classify the object, and him, as an existential threat of the highest order. He would spend the rest of his life in a box within a box, a permanent resident of their deepest, darkest hole. He needed to give them a threat they could understand, a problem they knew how to file. He had to translate the apocalypse into a manageable crisis. “It’s a weapon,” he managed to rasp, his voice raw. “A trap. It’s not sentient… it’s a mindless, psychic claymore. An area-denial device. The broadcast is designed to overload the cognitive functions of any organic mind in its vicinity, to induce catastrophic system failure. It’s a booby trap, left over from a war I can’t see.” It was the truth, but it was the truth from an altitude of ten thousand feet, concealing the horrifying, granular reality of its purpose.

Through the observation window, he saw Kaelen confer with Elias. His report seemed to satisfy them. A "psychic claymore" was a known quantity, a horror they could label and file. He had given them a neat, tidy box for their unutterable horror. Elias entered the lab, his face impassive, and gestured for Alfie to come. The consultation was over. He had performed his function. He was led back to his cell, the walk a blur of pain and disorientation. The door hissed shut, and he collapsed onto the bed, the white room spinning around him. He closed his eyes, but there was no darkness, no peace. There was only the faint, persistent, and terrifying flicker of a string of purple, geometric code, a cancerous seed of an alien world now planted in the silent, empty garden of his mind. He had survived his first day as a consultant. He now had a new and terrible secret, a poison he could not share, and a chilling certainty that the quiet war for his soul had just acquired a new, and deeply personal, front.### Chapter 10

The silence in the room was a physical weight, a thick blanket that smothered thought. But it could not smother the flicker. Alfie lay on the hard cot, his eyes squeezed shut, but the image was burned onto the inside of his eyelids, a persistent and horrifying afterimage. The string of glowing purple geometry pulsed in time with his own frantic heartbeat, a parasitic tattoo on his soul. It was not a memory; it was an active process. He could feel it, a tiny, cold engine of alien logic, testing the walls of his consciousness, seeking to interface with his own thoughts, to translate his memories and emotions into its own sterile, mathematical language. It was a single sentence from a book that could unwrite the universe, and he had become the page it was written on.

He pushed himself into a sitting position, a wave of dizziness and nausea washing over him. The metallic taste of blood was still thick in his mouth. He tried to erect the psychic shields he had used for years to keep the noisy echoes of the world at bay, a familiar fortress of will and quiet intention. It was utterly useless. The purple code did not try to breach his walls; it was already inside them. It operated on a level beneath thought, beneath emotion. It was a fundamental instruction, and his mind, his very soul, was the hardware it was running on. Fighting it with his old methods was like trying to stop a flood with a fishing net. The code wasn't an invading army; it was a subtle change in the laws of physics inside his own head.

A cold, desperate panic began to thread its way through the fog of his exhaustion. He was contaminated. Compromised. He was a walking time bomb, a carrier for a plague that could rewrite reality, and no one knew but him. His lie to Kaelen had been a brilliant act of self-preservation, but it had also been a death sentence. He had isolated himself completely, cutting off any hope of help from the very people who might understand the nature of the threat. He had traded a quick, clean death by a bullet for a slow, agonizing dissolution into something other. He fumbled at the harness on his chest, his fingers clumsy and numb. He tore at the flap of the lead-lined pouch, the simple act requiring an immense effort of will. His hand closed around the shard.

The relief was instantaneous and absolute. The moment his skin touched the shard's inert surface, the flickering purple geometry in his mind dimmed. The maddening, silent hum of its alien logic faded, suppressed by the shard's profound and perfect nothingness. It was like plunging a screaming radio into the deep ocean. The code wasn't gone—he could still sense it, a faint, frustrated presence huddled in a corner of his mind, walled off by the encroaching void of the shard—but it was silenced. He gasped, taking a deep, shuddering breath, the first clean breath he had taken since touching the artifact. The silence in the room was no longer oppressive; it was a sanctuary he had carved out for himself. The shard was no longer just leverage. It was his antidote. His anchor. The only thing keeping him himself.

He held the shard in his lap, a cold stone of salvation, and the terrible irony of his situation settled upon him. He was a prisoner of the Directorate, and they were his only protection from the outside world. He was a host to a psychic virus, and his only protection from it was the very object that had led him into this mess. He was a jailer holding the key to his own cage, a key that was also a poison, and his only freedom was a deeper, more profound imprisonment. He was trapped in a nesting doll of his own making, and at the very centre, a single, terrifying question began to form: what happened when the Directorate decided they wanted their key back for good?

The door hissed open, and Kaelen entered. This time, she came all the way into the room, her presence a sharp, clinical intrusion into his fragile peace. She held a data slate, but her focus was entirely on him. Her gaze dropped to the shard in his lap, then rose to meet his eyes. Her expression was, for the first time, not entirely neutral. There was a flicker of intense, scientific curiosity, the look of a biologist who has just seen a microbe perform a wholly unexpected trick. "Your neural activity," she began, her voice a precise, clipped monotone, "spiked to catastrophic levels upon your return to this room. Then, approximately ninety seconds ago, it stabilized to a level of calm that is statistically improbable for a subject in your circumstances. You have self-medicated. You are actively using the asset's null-field to suppress your own psychic trauma. That is… remarkable."

"I'm a remarkable man," Alfie said, his voice flat. He did not bother to hide the shard. It was better she believed it was a tool for his comfort rather than a weapon against an infection she knew nothing about. Let her think he was using it as a psychic crutch. It was a far safer explanation than the truth.

"Your deception regarding Item 734 has been logged and accepted," she continued, either ignoring or filing away his response. "Your designation of the object as a 'psychic claymore' fits within established parameters for xenocidal ordinance. You have proven your utility. As such, the Directorate has seen fit to grant you access to Level-Two amenities. Your 'consultations' have earned you a degree of trust." She offered him her data slate. On the screen was a schematic of a new room. It was larger than his cell, dominated by a heavy, metallic workbench and lined with shelves. On the shelves were dozens of objects, all sealed in clear, evidence-style containers. An old, rusted sextant. A tarnished silver locket. A child's spinning top made of pewter. They were pieces of his world, pieces of history.

"This is Workshop Seven," Kaelen explained. "All items within have been psychically sterilized. Their stories have been erased. They are blank slates. Your unique ability to… 'suggest' a state of being to ferrous materials is of great interest to us. We wish to observe it under controlled conditions. This workshop is your new cage, Mr. Blackwood. But it is a cage where you will be allowed to practice your craft. Consider it your reward. You will be escorted there in one hour." She took the slate back, turned, and left, the door hissing shut behind her. Alfie stared at the blank white wall, the silence rushing back in. A reward. A workshop full of dead things. They were going to give him a room full of corpses and ask him to teach them how to dance, all so they could learn how to build better weapons. And he knew, with a sinking, cold certainty, that he would go. He would go, because a cage with tools was better than a cage without, and he had a cancer in his soul that he desperately needed to learn how to cut out.

parts.text:
The rain in Barrow-in-Furness had a texture. Not just wet, but greasy, carrying the salt of the Irish Sea and the metallic tang of the shipyard on every drop. It coated the slate roofs of the terraced houses on Salthouse Road until they shone like polished jet, and it slicked the pavements with a treacherous sheen. Alfie Blackwood pulled the collar of his worn peacoat tighter, the coarse wool scratching at his neck. He hated this kind of weather. It got into the bones, a damp chill that no amount of tea or cheap whisky could fully exorcise. More than that, it warped the echoes. Water was a smudger, a great blurrer of residual energies, turning sharp memories into watercolour bleeds.

He stopped opposite the cordon. Two police cars were parked haphazardly, their blue lights painting silent, strobing patterns on the grim-faced brickwork of the tenement block. A small crowd of onlookers huddled under umbrellas, their faces pale and curious in the gloom of the late afternoon. Alfie ignored them. He wasn't here for the spectacle. He was here because Detective Inspector Morrison had called, and when Morrison called, it was never for a chat about the Bluebirds’ latest dismal performance.

Morrison was waiting for him just inside the tape, a hulking figure in a rumpled suit that looked like it had been slept in. And knowing Morrison, it probably had. His face was a roadmap of exhaustion, deep-set lines carved around his eyes and mouth. He held a steaming styrofoam cup that did little to warm his expression.

“Alfie. Thanks for coming.” His voice was a low rumble, thick with a Furness accent that had been weathered by decades of cigarettes and bad news. “It’s a rum one.”

“They always are, Dave,” Alfie said, ducking under the tape. “You don’t call me for the simple stuff.”

“Nowt simple about this.” Morrison gestured with his head towards the building's entrance. “Third floor. Flat 3B. Name’s Kevin Tiller. A fitter from the yard. Lived alone.”

“Lived?”

“Aye. He’s not living anymore.”

The communal stairwell stank of stale cabbage and damp. The lino was cracked, the wallpaper peeling in long, jaundiced strips. Alfie’s boots made soft, squelching sounds on the worn steps. He could feel the building’s history pressing in on him, a century of minor miseries and fleeting joys soaked into the very plaster. It was a low, constant hum, the background noise of his life. Most people felt it as a vague sense of unease or nostalgia. For Alfie, it was like listening to a thousand quiet conversations at once. He’d learned to tune it out, to turn the volume down until it was just a faint static at the edge of his senses.

The door to 3B was ajar, a uniformed constable standing beside it with a carefully blank expression. Inside, the flat was small and surprisingly tidy. A threadbare sofa, a television, a shelf of naval history books. But the orderliness of the living room only made the chaos in the small workshop beyond it more jarring.

Kevin Tiller was on the floor, amidst a scatter of metal shavings and specialised tools. He was on his back, eyes wide and staring at the ceiling, a single, dark hole in the centre of his forehead. There was no blood. None. The edges of the wound were cauterised, blackened and seared into the skin.

“Forensics are stumped,” Morrison muttered, staying by the doorway. “No entry wound at the back. No projectile. No scorch marks on anything else in the room. Just… that.”

Alfie didn't answer. He was already scanning the room, his eyes not just seeing but *feeling*. The air was thick with a residue, a sharp, cold spike of power that felt utterly alien. It was like a perfectly cut sliver of ice jammed into the warm, messy hum of the building. Purposeful. Precise. And utterly without passion. He walked slowly around the body, careful not to touch anything. His gaze fell on the workbench. It was covered in intricate metal sculptures, small, beautiful things crafted from scrap. Birds with bolt-heads for eyes, ships with hulls of beaten copper pipe. Kevin Tiller had been an artist.

And then he saw it. Lying beside Tiller’s outstretched hand was a single, heavy-duty rivet, the kind used to plate the submarines built in the Devonshire Dock Hall. It looked ordinary. Unremarkable. But to Alfie’s senses, it was screaming.

“The rivet,” Alfie said, his voice quiet. “That’s it.”

Morrison frowned. “The lads have bagged everything else. That was just lying there. Probably dropped it.”

“He didn’t drop it.” Alfie knelt, his knees cracking. He pulled a thin leather glove from his coat pocket and carefully picked up the rivet. Even through the leather, the chill was intense. A soul-deep cold that had nothing to do with temperature. It felt… hungry. He held it for a moment, then looked at Morrison. “I need to be alone with this, Dave. And I need somewhere quiet. No electrics. No chatter.”

Morrison’s expression was a mixture of scepticism and resignation. He’d seen Alfie work before, but he’d never understood it. He didn’t need to. He just needed the results. “The old morgue at the station. It’s just a storage cellar now. Will that do?”

“Perfect,” Alfie said, his eyes fixed on the metal object in his gloved hand. “It’ll do just reet.”

The cellar was cold, musty, and blessedly silent. A single, bare bulb hung from the ceiling, but Alfie had Morrison kill the power. He preferred the dark. It made the other things easier to see. He placed the rivet on a cold, slate slab that had once held bodies and now held dusty archive boxes. He took off his glove. The air was still. So still.

He was a warlock. A ridiculous word for a ridiculous job. It conjured images of pointy hats and bubbling cauldrons, not a bloke in a peacoat from Barrow who could read the stories left on old metal. His was a grubby, industrial sort of magic, born of the iron and steel that had defined his hometown for generations. He didn't cast spells; he coaxed secrets. He didn't scry in crystal balls; he saw history in a rust stain.

Taking a deep, steadying breath, he pressed his bare thumb against the cold, smooth head of the rivet.

And the world fractured.

It wasn't a vision, not a film played behind his eyes. It was a plunge. He was the rivet. He was cold steel, forged in fire and pressure, waiting in a dusty bin. Then a hand—Tiller’s hand, calloused and strong—plucked him out. The scent of oil and sweat. The feel of the man’s workbench, the vibration of a file against a neighbouring piece of scrap. He felt Tiller’s frustration, the creative block he was fighting. He wanted to build something new, something different.

Then the air in the workshop changed. The low hum of the television in the next room vanished, replaced by an absolute, crushing silence. A new presence. Cold. Arrogant. Alfie felt it through Tiller’s skin, a prickling on the back of his neck. Tiller turned. A figure stood in the doorway. Tall, silhouetted against the light from the hall. Alfie couldn’t see a face, just a shape. A long coat. A sense of stillness that was more menacing than any sudden movement.

The figure raised a hand. There was no incantation, no word spoken. Just a gathering of… nothing. A point of absolute cold and shadow coalesced in the air between them. Tiller, holding the rivet, took an instinctive step back, his heart hammering a frantic rhythm that vibrated through the metal in his hand.

The point of shadow shot forward. It wasn't a projectile; it was a puncture in reality. It moved without sound, without disturbing the air. It struck Tiller in the forehead.

And through the rivet, Alfie felt the man’s life unravel. Not just stop. Unravel. Memories, sensations, emotions—all pulled, thread by thread, from his body, drawn into the impossible cold of the wound. It was an obliteration. A consumption. Alfie felt Tiller’s last thought, not of fear, but of confusion. A simple, heartbreaking *Why?*

The life force, a torrent of energy, was sucked into the void. But not all of it. A tiny, stray spark, a flicker of Tiller’s dying essence, lashed out in its death throe. It didn't strike the attacker. It struck the nearest, most conductive object. The rivet in his hand.

The vision ended. Alfie snatched his thumb back as if burned, stumbling away from the slate slab. He was gasping, sweat beading on his forehead despite the cellar's chill. The echo wasn't just a memory of the event; it was the event itself, imprinted on the metal, and with it, a sliver of Kevin Tiller’s stolen soul. That was the source of the unnatural cold. The rivet was a tiny lich-object, a phylactery by accident.

But that wasn't what shook Alfie to his core. It was the magic. The precise, silent, soul-devouring cold. He had felt it once before, years ago. A rumour. A whisper in the hidden corners of the world he inhabited. A style of magic, a philosophy of power that treated life not as sacred, but as fuel. They called it the Umbral Hand. A nihilistic cabal that believed in power through erasure.

And as the last fragments of the vision faded from his mind, one final image burned itself into his memory. Just for a second, as the killer lowered his hand, a sign had shimmered in the air where the magic had been woven. Not a physical light, but a sigil of pure absence, a mark that drank the light around it. A spiralling serpent, endlessly consuming its own tail, but with a shard of obsidian at its centre.

Malachi’s sigil.

Alfie’s breath hitched. No. It couldn't be. Malachi was a ghost story, a bogeyman that elder warlocks used to scare apprentices. A cautionary tale about ambition and the pursuit of power for its own sake. A prodigy who had vanished from the circles decades ago, presumed dead or driven mad by his own dark arts.

But that sigil was unmistakable. And it was here. In Barrow-in-Furness. In a tidy little flat, murdering a man who made sculptures out of scrap metal. It made no sense. None of it.

He leaned against the cold brick wall, the damp seeping into his coat. He could still feel the echo of Tiller’s final, confused thought. *Why?*

It was a good question. A question that was going to get him into a world of trouble. Because Malachi, ghost story or not, had just made it personal. He’d left a calling card. And Alfie Blackwood was the only one in this salt-sprayed, forgotten corner of the country who knew how to read it. A cold dread, far deeper than the cellar's chill, began to settle in his stomach. This wasn't just a murder. This was a message. This was the beginning of something.

He pushed himself off the wall, his joints protesting. The cellar suddenly felt less like a sanctuary and more like a tomb. The rivet on the slab no longer seemed like a simple piece of metal; it was a gravestone, a tiny, cold monument to a stolen life. He couldn't leave it here. It was evidence, yes, but not for Morrison's world. It was a piece of Tiller, a fragment of a soul trapped in steel, and leaving it in a police evidence bag felt like a final, unforgivable violation. With his gloved hand, he picked it up and slipped it deep into his peacoat pocket, where it rested against his hip like a cold stone.

He climbed the stairs, emerging from the quiet dark into the harsh fluorescent buzz of the station's back corridor. The transition was jarring. Here, the world was mundane, brightly lit, and smelled of cheap floor polish and lukewarm coffee. Morrison was leaning against a filing cabinet, talking to the uniformed constable who had been at the flat. He looked up as Alfie approached, his brow furrowed with impatient hope.

“Well?” Morrison’s voice was a gravelly demand. “Did your… thing… give you anything? Or have you just been communing with the dust bunnies?”

Alfie paused, choosing his words as carefully as he would pick his way through a room full of unstable enchantments. He couldn't tell the truth. The truth involved soul-eating sorcery and a bogeyman from a hidden world. The truth would get him a padded cell, not a case file. He had to translate the impossible into the merely improbable.

“It’s not a gun, Dave. Not in any way we’d understand it,” Alfie began, his voice low and even. “There was no bullet. The wound… it’s like a puncture, but made of energy. Something that burns and freezes at the same time. It’s highly focused. Almost surgical.”

Morrison scowled, rubbing a hand over his tired face. “Energy? What are you talking about? Like a laser?”

“No. A laser would have burned the whole room. This was contained. Precise. It didn't just kill him; it did something *to* him. It took something. Think of it less like a firearm and more like… a specialised industrial tool. Something experimental. Maybe military. Something that isn’t supposed to exist outside of a black-ops lab.” He hated the lie, hated the theatre of it, but it was a necessary bridge between his world and Morrison’s. It pointed towards secrecy, advanced technology, and ruthless perpetrators—all things a detective could understand and investigate.

Morrison absorbed this, his policeman’s mind sifting it for workable angles. “Experimental tech? Here? In Barrow? Who was this Tiller bloke to get hit with something like that? He was a fitter. He liked history books and made little metal birds.”

“I don’t know,” Alfie admitted, and that part was entirely true. “Maybe he saw something at the shipyard he shouldn't have. Maybe he stumbled into something. The motive is a blank. But the killer… they’re professional. Quiet. They left nothing behind. No physical trace. They wanted to be a ghost.”

“They left the body,” Morrison grumbled.

“They left a statement,” Alfie corrected softly. “This wasn’t about killing Kevin Tiller. It was about *how* he was killed.” He tapped his coat pocket, where the rivet lay cold and heavy. “That rivet you were going to bag. I need to hold onto it.”

Morrison’s eyes narrowed. “Evidence, Alfie. I can’t just let you walk out with it.”

“What’s it evidence of? A man dropping a rivet in his own workshop?” Alfie met his gaze. “To your forensics, it’s a lump of scrap metal. Let me have it. Let me see what else it can tell me. You’re chasing a ghost with no prints, no weapon, and no motive. Your labs will find nothing. You know they won’t. This is your only lead, Dave, even if you don't understand it.”

The detective stood there for a long moment, the hum of the lights filling the silence between them. He was a man of procedure, of tangible facts and witness statements. Alfie was his wild card, his trip into the twilight zone that he tolerated only because, more than once, it had yielded a result he couldn't have gotten any other way. With a sigh that seemed to draw up all the exhaustion in the world, he gave a curt, reluctant nod.

“Fine. But you call me. You find out what a ‘fitter from the yard’ was doing to get zapped by a sci-fi ray gun, and you call me the second you do. I don’t want to read about it in some UFO-spotter’s newsletter first.”

“You’ll be my first call,” Alfie promised. Another small lie. His first call, if he made one at all, would be to someone who understood what a spiralling serpent with a shard of obsidian at its heart truly meant. And he dreaded making that call more than anything.

He turned and walked away, not waiting for a dismissal. He pushed through the station doors and back out into the greasy Barrow evening. The rain had eased to a persistent, clinging drizzle. It wasn’t a smudger of echoes anymore; it felt like a shroud, muffling the town in a blanket of damp misery. The streetlights cast long, distorted reflections on the wet pavement, turning the familiar road into something alien and unwelcoming.

He pulled his collar tight again, but the chill he felt now had nothing to do with the weather. Malachi. Here. Why? The question beat in his mind like a second heart. It couldn't be a coincidence. Warlocks of Malachi's calibre didn't do things by accident. Every move was a sentence in a larger statement. Murdering a seemingly insignificant man in a forgotten corner of the country wasn’t a random act of violence. It was the first line of a new chapter. And Alfie Blackwood, reader of metal and rust, was terrified he was the only one in the city who had been given the book.

## Chapter 2

Alfie’s flat was on a side street off Abbey Road, a top-floor conversion in a solid old Victorian house that had once belonged to a ship's captain. The walk there was a familiar litany of cracked paving stones and the faint, ever-present scent of fried food from a distant takeaway. Tonight, though, every shadow seemed to stretch a little too far, and the sound of his own footsteps seemed unnervingly loud in the damp quiet. The rivet was a point of absolute cold in his pocket, a psychic deadweight that made his hip ache. He carried it like a disease, a secret that separated him from the oblivious, rain-soaked figures he passed on the street. They were worried about bills, about the football scores, about getting home to a hot meal. He was worried about a sorcerer who ate souls.

His home was his sanctuary, a meticulously controlled environment. There were no smart speakers, no wifi router blinking in the corner. The only technology was a twenty-year-old television that was rarely switched on and a sturdy landline telephone. The rest of the space was filled with books and metal. Not the screaming, imprinted metal of the outside world, but quiet things he had found and patiently ‘cleansed’ over the years: old engine parts, Victorian ironmongery, lumps of raw haematite from the Cumbrian fells. They filled the shelves and lined the mantelpiece, each one a silent, grounding presence. He had curated his silence, building a fortress not of brick, but of sensory nullity. It was the only way he could ever feel truly alone and at peace.

He didn't dare leave the rivet out on a surface. It was more than an object; it was a wound in the fabric of the room, its unnatural chill a constant, weeping reminder of the murder. From a heavy oak chest in the corner, he retrieved a small, lead-lined box, the kind once used for transporting photographic plates. He had a few of them, reserved for objects too loud, too violent, to be left exposed. Placing the gloved rivet inside and closing the heavy lid felt like shutting a coffin. The oppressive cold in the room lessened immediately, but he could still feel it, a faint, insistent thrum of stolen life locked in the dark. It pulsed like a migraine behind his eyes, a sliver of Kevin Tiller’s final, terrified moments, now a permanent part of his quiet space.

He stood in the centre of his living room for a long time, the low hum of the streetlights outside the only sound. He couldn't do this alone. The lie to Morrison had bought him time, but it was a flimsy shield against the truth of the matter. Malachi’s sigil wasn’t a challenge; it was a declaration. It was an announcement that the rules had changed, and that the old ghost stories were stepping out of the shadows. The thought made his hands feel cold and clumsy. He ran a hand through his damp hair, his gaze falling on the old black rotary phone on his sideboard. There was only one person he could call. One person who might have an inkling of the scale of this, who dealt not in whispers and rust, but in the lore and law of their hidden world. Elara Vance. The name tasted like dust and regret. She had been his mentor, of a sort, decades ago, the Keeper of the Athenaeum of the Unseen, a grand title for a woman who ran a secret, crumbling library of forbidden knowledge from a basement in Manchester. He had walked away from that world, from its rigid hierarchies and its dangerous politics, preferring the solitary grime of Barrow. To call her now was to admit defeat. It was to confess that his small, quiet life was no longer enough to protect him.

With a heavy sense of inevitability, he walked to the sideboard, lifted the heavy bakelite receiver, and dialled the number from memory. It rang four times, each buzz echoing the frantic hammering in his chest. He was about to hang up when the line clicked open. There was no greeting, just an expectant silence.
“Elara,” he said, his voice hoarse.
“Blackwood.” Her voice was exactly as he remembered: dry as old parchment and sharp enough to cut glass. “To what do I owe the disruption? Have you finally rusted shut in that dreadful northern port you call a home?”
“I need some information,” he said, ignoring the jibe. “A murder. Here. In Barrow.”
“I’m not a policewoman. And you, if I recall, are no longer a part of any organisation that would concern itself with such matters. You made your choice to become a provincial antiquarian of scrap.”
“The method, Elara,” Alfie cut in, his patience fraying. “It was cold. Precise. It unravelled the victim. No passion, just… consumption.” He paused, forcing the next words out. “He left a sigil. A serpent eating its own tail, with a shard of obsidian at the centre.”
The silence on the other end of the line was suddenly different. The dismissive, academic quiet was replaced by something sharp and absolute, like an indrawn breath. When she finally spoke, all trace of arid wit was gone, replaced by a cold, deadly seriousness. “Where did you see this, Alfie?”
“In the echo. On the murder weapon.”
“Malachi,” she whispered, and the name itself felt like a drop in temperature over the phone line. “The sigil of the Umbral Hand. You fool. You absolute fool. That wasn’t a calling card left for the police. It was a baited hook. It was left for anyone like you who came sniffing around. By reading it, you’ve announced yourself. You’ve rung his dinner bell.”

A cold dread, far worse than the rivet’s chill, washed over Alfie. He had thought he was the reader, the observer. He had never considered that he was the one being read. “Bogeyman,” he muttered, more to himself than to her. “Everyone said he was just a story.”
“He was a cautionary tale that everyone hoped was a myth,” Elara snapped. “He founded the Hand on the principle that life, that a soul, is just a resource to be harvested. He vanished forty years ago because the old guard hunted him to the brink of extinction. We all assumed he was dead. We were wrong. He was rebuilding. Growing stronger in the dark. He does not act without purpose, Alfie. The victim, this Tiller, is irrelevant. Malachi was after something Tiller had, or something he knew. And now, he will be after what *you* know. You must get rid of the object you read. Destroy it.”
“I can’t,” Alfie said, his hand tightening on the receiver. “There’s a piece of the victim’s soul trapped in it. An echo of his life.”
There was a sigh, a weary, ancient sound. “Then you are in more trouble than I can possibly convey over a telephone line. Find out what Tiller had. Find out what Malachi wants. Find it before he finds you. And Alfie… don’t call this number again. It’s a liability I can no longer afford.” The line went dead, leaving Alfie in the oppressive silence of his flat, the dial tone a shrill, mocking lament.

He was marked. A target. The quiet life he had built for himself was over. Panic was a rising tide, but he forced it down. Panic was a luxury. He needed more than the memory of a murder; he needed a reason. He needed to know what had brought this nightmare to Kevin Tiller’s door. He walked back to the lead-lined box and opened it. The rivet lay inside, inert and cold. To touch it again, to deliberately plunge back into that violation, felt like an act of self-mutilation. But Elara was right. It was his only path forward. He took the rivet out with his bare hand this time, the cold searing his palm, and walked to the centre of the room. He closed his eyes, took a deep, ragged breath, and focused not on the sharp spike of the murder, but on the fainter, warmer hum beneath it. He pushed past the screaming echo of death, searching for the quiet whisper of life that had come before.

The plunge was disorienting, a chaotic swirl of fragmented images. Not a film, but a box of old photographs thrown in the air. The tang of welding fumes. The heft of a hammer. The satisfaction of a perfectly flush joint. The grey, churning expanse of the Irish Sea seen from the top of the Devonshire Dock Hall. Then, a memory sharpened, crystallising out of the blur. It was Tiller, but younger. He wasn’t in the main yard. He was on a smaller, grittier job, part of a crew contracted for demolition at the old VSEL works on the far side of Walney Island, a place that had been left to rot for decades. They were breaking up an old, concrete-and-steel submarine pen, one that hadn't been used since the fifties. The memory was thick with the smell of rust and salt and decay. Tiller was guiding a crane operator, clearing a collapsed section of the sea wall, when they found it. A dark shape, wedged deep in the foundations. It was a piece of wreckage, gnarled and ancient, covered in layers of marine growth. But as the crane tore it loose, a section broke off. It wasn't rusted metal. It was something else. A material as black as coal, but with a strange, non-reflective surface that seemed to drink the weak sunlight. It felt dense, heavy in Tiller's memory-hand, and weirdly inert. To Tiller, the artist, it was a fascinating new medium. To Alfie, feeling it through the echo, it was terrifying. It had no story. It was psychically blank, a void in a world where everything had a history. Tiller, fascinated and breaking every rule in the book, pocketed a small, fist-sized shard of the strange, black material before the foreman could see.

The vision shattered, dumping Alfie back onto his own two feet in the middle of his living room. He was shivering violently, the rivet now feeling almost hot in his palm. He dropped it as if it were a burning coal. He knew. He knew what Malachi was after. It wasn't Kevin Tiller, the gentle sculptor of scrap. It was Tiller the magpie, the man who had found a piece of something that shouldn't exist and taken it home. The murder was nothing more than a brutal acquisition. A new question, colder and sharper than any that had come before, lodged itself in Alfie’s brain. What in God's name was this silent, history-less black material, and what could a warlock who fed on the very essence of life want with something that had none? He was no longer just solving a murder. He was standing between a predator of unimaginable power and a prize he couldn't begin to comprehend. The hunt was on, and Alfie Blackwood was now officially the prey.

The rivet clattered on the floorboards, a jarring, metallic sound in the profound stillness of the room. Alfie stared at it, his hand throbbing not with heat or cold, but with a deep, aching emptiness where the vision had been. The memory of the black, history-less material was a void in his mind, an impossible contradiction to the fundamental laws of his world. Everything had a story. A cracked teacup held the echo of a thousand morning arguments; a rusted nail held the memory of the hammer’s blow and the carpenter’s sweat. But this material Tiller had found was a cipher, a page torn from the book of existence before any words could be written on it.

He understood now. Malachi, the ultimate consumer, who fed on the rich tapestry of life and memory, had found its antithesis. An object of pure absence. What would he want with it? To study it? To destroy it? Or to somehow weaponise that nothingness? The question was a black hole in itself, pulling all other thoughts into its orbit. The horror of Tiller’s death was now eclipsed by the terrifying implications of its motive. This was bigger than a single murder in a backwater town. This was about a fundamental principle of power.

Panic was a physical thing, a tightening in his chest, a frantic fluttering in his gut. His sanctuary, this flat he had so carefully insulated from the world’s psychic noise, now felt like a cage. Malachi’s sigil was a brand on his mind's eye, and Elara’s warning was a death knell. *You’ve rung his dinner bell.* He couldn’t stay here. The hunter was coming, and Alfie had just pinpointed the location of the treasure map. He had to get to the shard first. It was the only card he had to play, the only piece of leverage in a game where his own soul was the ante.

The workshop. It had to be there. Tiller the artist would have kept his most fascinating, most unusual find close to his other materials. But the flat was a crime scene, sealed and guarded. He couldn't go to Morrison. The bridge of lies he’d built between their worlds was too fragile to bear the weight of a request to re-enter an active murder investigation based on a psychic hunch. There was only one way. He had to go back to Salthouse Road and break in. The thought felt reckless, suicidal even, but staying put felt like a slower, more certain death.

He forced himself to move, his actions deliberate and methodical, a bulwark against the rising fear. He put the rivet back in its lead-lined box and slid the box into his deep peacoat pocket. It was his compass, his connection to Tiller's last moments, and a terrible burden. From under his bed, he pulled a small, worn leather roll containing a set of old locksmith's tools, the metal gleaming dully. They were relics of a misspent youth, skills he hadn't needed for twenty years, but like everything in his life, he had kept them. You never knew when the past might become useful. He pulled on a dark woollen hat and a pair of thin leather gloves, his reflection in the hall mirror a grim, shadowy figure he barely recognised. The warlock of rust and echoes was about to become a common burglar.

The streets of Barrow were emptier now, the rain having driven most people indoors. The night air was thick and cold, each breath a damp shock to the lungs. Every flicker of a curtain in a window, every car that swept its headlights down the street, felt like a threat. Paranoia was a new and unwelcome companion, whispering at the edge of his senses. He felt exposed, his every step a drumbeat announcing his position to the unseen hunter. He kept to the back alleys and unlit ginnels, his path a dark mirror of the town’s official geography, a route known only to cats, foxes, and men with things to hide.

Salthouse Road was quiet. The police cars were gone, but the blue and white tape still stretched across the tenement's entrance, a flimsy, plastic ghost of the earlier drama. A single streetlamp cast a sickly orange glow over the wet brick, making the building look even more haggard and grim. There was no uniformed officer on watch. Morrison was running a stretched-thin force, and with no obvious suspect, a static guard on a sealed flat was a luxury they couldn't afford overnight. Alfie slipped into the shadows of the alley that ran alongside the building, his heart pounding against his ribs. The air here was thick with the stink of overflowing bins and stale beer. He looked up. Third floor. Tiller’s window was dark. He found the drainpipe, a sturdy, cast-iron relic of Victorian plumbing. It was slick with greasy rain, but the brackets were solid. With a grunt, he began to climb, the coarse metal cold and unforgiving under his gloved hands.

The window to the flat’s small bathroom was cracked, held together with yellowing tape. It was a flimsy defence. Using the butt of a heavy tension wrench, he gave the corner a sharp, carefully muffled rap. The glass fractured with a dull crunch. He picked out the broken shards, creating a hole big enough to snake his arm through and unlatch the simple catch. He slid the window open and hoisted himself inside, landing with a soft thud on the worn lino. The flat was cold and silent, but it was a different silence from before. It was the sterile, violated silence of a place that had been picked over by strangers. A fine layer of black fingerprint dust coated the doorframes and light switches. Small plastic evidence markers dotted the floor of the living room.

He moved silently towards the workshop, his senses on high alert. The psychic residue of the murder was still there, a sharp, cold spike, but it was overlaid now with the echoes of the forensics team—their professional detachment, their muttered conversations, their faint, lingering scent of latex and coffee. He stepped into the workshop and his breath caught. The place had been turned upside-down. Tools were laid out in neat rows for photographing, Tiller’s beautiful, half-finished metal sculptures now sat in numbered evidence bags. They were searching for a weapon, for clues, for anything that fit their version of the world. They were looking in all the wrong places.

Alfie began his own search. Where would an artist hide his most precious, secret material? Not in a box. Not on a shelf. He would make it a part of his art. Alfie’s gaze moved over the bagged sculptures. A seabird with wings of beaten tin. A submarine conning tower made from an old kettle. And then he saw it. A larger piece, left on the bench, presumably too heavy or awkward to have been bagged yet. It was an abstract sculpture, a swirling vortex of welded nuts, bolts, and rebar, meant to evoke a whirlpool or a galaxy. It was chaotic, dynamic, and at its very centre, where all the spiralling metal converged, was a single point of absolute blackness.

He carefully slit the evidence bag with a small knife from his kit and reached inside. The metal of the sculpture was cold, humming with the faint, residual energy of its creator’s hands. But as his fingers closed around the fist-sized, black object at its core, all sensation vanished. It wasn't just cold. It was a sensory vacuum. His psychometric gift, the constant stream of information that defined his perception of the world, hit a wall of absolute nothing. It was like staring into a starless patch of night sky, like listening to a silence so profound it hurt the ears. It had no texture, no temperature, no story. It was a hole in reality he could hold in his hand. This was it. This was what Malachi had killed for.

As his fingers tightened around the shard, a new sensation rippled through the flat. It wasn't an echo from the past; it was a tremor in the present. A cold, deliberate pulse of focused will, sweeping through the building like a searchlight. It was a magical probe, subtle and impossibly refined, but to Alfie’s heightened senses it felt like a physical blow. Someone was checking on the location. Malachi, or one of his acolytes. They were looking for the shard, or for him. Elara’s voice echoed in his mind. *You’ve rung his dinner bell.* The probe swept past him, not detecting him—perhaps the shard in his hand was shielding him, its own nullity acting as a cloak. But he knew it would be back. He had moments.

Clutching the shard, Alfie scrambled back towards the bathroom window, his stealth forgotten. He tumbled out onto the narrow ledge, his heart hammering. He didn't dare use the drainpipe again. Instead, he dropped into the foul-smelling alley, landing hard in a pile of sodden cardboard boxes that cushioned his fall with a wet squelch. He got to his feet and ran, not looking back. He didn't stop until he was several streets away, huddled in the darkness of a railway underpass, the rumble of a passing freight train overhead shaking the very ground. He leaned against the cold, damp brick, gasping for air, the impossible black shard clutched in his hand. His flat wasn't safe. The station wasn't safe. Nowhere in Barrow was safe. He had stolen the prize from under the hunter’s nose, and in doing so, had turned his entire life into a crime scene. He was alone, marked, and holding an object that defied the laws of his existence. The hunt was no longer a distant threat; it was on his heels.

## Chapter 3

The freight train passed, its clattering roar fading into the damp night, leaving a ringing silence in its wake. Alfie pressed himself against the cold, weeping brick of the underpass, his breath fogging in the air. He was a fugitive in his own hometown, a ghost haunting the grimy arteries of a place he knew better than the lines on his own hand. He uncurled his fingers. The black shard lay on his palm, a patch of pure absence. It didn't feel cold or warm; it felt of nothing. Holding it was like having a small piece of his sensory perception amputated. In his other pocket, the lead box containing the rivet was a point of agonizing, soul-deep cold, a screaming counterpoint to the shard's unnerving silence. He was carrying both the crime and the motive, a walking repository of a dead man's tragedy.

His flat was a beacon for the hunter now. Every object he had ever touched was a psychic breadcrumb leading back to him. Elara’s warning had made it clear: Malachi wasn't just powerful, he was a predator who understood the nature of the hunt. Staying still was suicide. But running felt just as futile. Where could he go? Every hotel, every boarding house, was a trap of transient energies and paper-thin walls. He had no allies left to call on, no secret boltholes prepared for such an eventuality. He had traded that life of conspiracy and safe-houses for the quiet solitude of Barrow, and now his solitude had become his prison.

Then, the answer came to him, not as a thought, but as an instinct. It rose from the very core of his being, from the industrial magic that ran in his blood. To hide a tree, you put it in a forest. To hide a man whose entire world was defined by the echoes of metal, you put him in a cathedral of it. The shipyard. It was the heart of the town, a sprawling, hundred-acre labyrinth of steel and concrete, of cavernous construction halls and graveyards of rusting marine equipment. It was the loudest psychic environment for miles, a constant, deafening symphony of a century of industry, of triumphs and tragedies, of countless lives spent shaping steel. To Malachi’s magical probe, searching for the specific whisper of Alfie's personal resonance, diving into the shipyard would be like trying to hear a single voice in a football stadium during a goal. It was a desperate gamble, but it was the only one he had.

The decision made, a sliver of purpose cut through his fear. He pushed himself from the wall and began to move, sticking to the warren of backstreets that skirted the town centre. He saw his home through the eyes of a hunted animal, every familiar landmark now a potential ambush point. The warm yellow light of the chip shop on the corner seemed menacing, the distant chime of a church bell felt like a warning. He was an exile in his own kingdom of rust.

Getting into the BAE Systems site was, for most people, impossible. It was one of the most secure industrial locations in the United Kingdom, ringed with high fences, cameras, and patrols. But Alfie wasn’t most people. He had grown up in the shadow of the Devonshire Dock Hall, and he knew the yard's perimeter had weak points, forgotten corners where the new fences met the old Victorian walls, where the surveillance was designed to watch for threats coming from the sea, not from a man crawling through a forgotten culvert that emptied onto the mudflats. He found his spot near a disused railway spur, a place where a section of crumbling brick wall was hidden by a thicket of gorse and brambles. It was a tight squeeze, the thorns tearing at his peacoat, but he wriggled through, emerging into the vast, alien landscape of the yard.

The scale of the place was overwhelming. The DDH, the main construction hall, loomed over him like a mountain range, its vast metal sides blocking out the stars. The air hummed with the sound of industrial ventilation and the distant, percussive clang of metal on metal from a night shift crew. But beneath that, the psychic roar was immense. It hit him like a physical wave, a chaotic jumble of energy that made the background hum of the town seem like a whisper. It was perfect. He was a needle in a haystack made of needles. He moved deeper into the yard, a shadow amongst larger shadows, heading for the older, quieter western edge where the ghosts of the yard were left to rust in peace. He found what he was looking for in a quiet corner of the docks: a row of decommissioned Oberon-class submarines, Cold War relics slowly surrendering to the salt and the rain. They were skeletal, silent leviathans, their black hulls streaked with decades of rust that looked like dried blood in the dim security lighting.

One of them, the HMS Onyx, had a hatch on its forward casing that had been forced long ago by souvenir hunters or curious teenagers. It was a dark, unwelcoming mouth. Taking a deep, steadying breath that tasted of decay and brine, Alfie lowered himself into the absolute blackness of the submarine's interior. The hatch clanged shut above him, plunging him into a tomb-like silence broken only by the drip of water and the mournful groan of the old hull settling in the tide. The psychic noise was different in here; it was focused, contained. He could feel the claustrophobic echoes of half a century of service, the tension of long patrols in the deep, the boredom, the camaraderie. It was a thick, protective blanket. He was safe, for now.

He felt his way forward into the control room. His hand brushed against a command console, and a blizzard of fleeting images flooded his mind: a young officer’s hand on the periscope controls, the green glow of the sonar screen, the taste of stale coffee. He shook it off and sat down on the cold deck plating, his back against the bulkhead. He couldn't run forever. He needed to stop being the prey. He had to understand his enemy, and he had to lighten his load. He pulled the lead box from his pocket and opened it. The rivet’s cold, desperate energy filled the small space. He couldn’t carry this fragment of Kevin Tiller’s soul forever. It was a violation, and its screaming psychic presence was a liability. He had to let it go.

He placed the rivet on the steel deck. Pressing his bare hands flat on the plating on either side of it, he closed his eyes and reached out with his senses. He wasn't trying to read the rivet this time, but to connect with the immense, ancient spirit of the submarine itself. He sank his consciousness into the metal, feeling the echoes of the thousands of men who had served here, the deep, resonant history of the iron that had been mined, forged, and welded to create this vessel. He became a part of its story. Then, gently, he extended that vast, collective energy towards the tiny, screaming rivet. He didn't try to fight the echo of the murder; he simply opened a door. He offered the trapped, terrified spark of Kevin Tiller’s essence a way out, a path to dissolve not into nothingness, but into the vast, collective memory of the iron hulk. *You're not alone,* he projected, not with words, but with a feeling of grounding, of homecoming. *Rest in the steel. Be part of the story.*

For a moment, the cold, sharp point of Tiller's end fought back, a frantic pulse of fear and confusion. Then, it seemed to sense the vast, peaceful weight of the submarine's history surrounding it. The screaming quieted. The sharp edges of the echo softened, bleeding out into the deck plates. Alfie felt a final, fleeting impression from the rivet: not a thought, not an image, but a wave of profound, weary gratitude. Then, it was over. The unnatural cold vanished. He lifted his hands. The rivet was still there, but it was just a rivet now. A simple, mundane piece of metal, its terrible story told and its burden released. It was silent. Alfie picked it up and slipped it into his pocket. It was just a keepsake now, a reminder. He leaned his head back against the cold steel of the submarine, the silence of the control room feeling less like a tomb and more like a sanctuary. The shard was still a void in his pocket, a question mark that threatened to unravel his world. But he had taken his first step. He had stopped running and started acting. Out in the rainy darkness of Barrow-in-Furness, the hunter was still searching, but in the belly of a dead iron fish, Alfie Blackwood was finally beginning to think about how to fight back.

The silence that followed was profound. It was a heavy, metallic quiet, the natural peace of a forgotten place, no longer marred by the psychic scream of a murdered man. Alfie sat on the cold steel deck of the HMS Onyx, a deep, bone-weary exhaustion settling over him like a shroud. The release of Tiller’s echo had drained him, but it had also cleansed him. ## Chapter 6

He picked up the shard. It felt no different, a smooth, inert void in his palm. He extended his senses towards it, not to read it, but to push against it. He focused a tiny, controlled thread of his own energy—a sliver of a memory, the taste of whisky on a cold night—and directed it into the shard. It vanished. There was no resistance, no reaction, just an effortless, absolute absorption. The energy didn't bounce off; it simply ceased to exist. He tried again, with a stronger, more complex echo—the feeling of his father’s hand on his shoulder, heavy with calluses and pride. The shard took it without a flicker. Not a blade to stab Malachi, but a poison pill to be fed to him.

The Devonshire Dock Hall.

He reached inward, to the core of his own being, to the faint, warm spark of his own soul. He didn't try to suppress it. Instead, he carefully and deliberately wrapped it around the null-shard, using the object's void as a mould. He inverted his own presence, making his life-force a thin, shimmering shell around an immense core of absolute nothing. It was an act of profound psychic contortion, a lie told with the very essence of his existence. To an outside observer, especially one whose senses were attuned to the consumption of life force, he would no longer appear as Alfie Blackwood, a minor industrial warlock. The echoes of a million hammer blows, of a thousand triumphant launch days, of the quiet pride of generations of builders, all flowed into him, a torrent of raw, human will. He cast it out from the hall, a psychic beacon that lanced through the chaos of the town square and struck the mind of the one it was intended for. It did not carry words. The psychic storm over Barrow ceased instantly. The riot of echoes, the cacophony of madness, all of it vanished, sucked back into a single point of cold, malevolent attention. ## Chapter 7

The shadow did not grow; it deepened. But the predator, in its final, gluttonous lunge, did not strike the tender soul it expected. It struck the lie. Its all-consuming power slammed into the perfect, indigestible void of the null-shard. ## Chapter 8
