“Kevin Tiller is dead,” Alfie stated, the name a heavy stone in the air. “The police have a body with a hole in its head and no weapon. I was their only lead, their weirdo consultant. I’ve since broken into a sealed crime scene and two high-security industrial sites. I am not a missing person, I am a suspect. You sanitize the area. That’s your job, isn’t it? So sanitize me. Make Alfie Blackwood, the oddball from Abbey Road, disappear. Give me a clean slate. Do that, and your Directorate gets its new ‘anomalous biologic’. And its asset.”

The woman considered his terms for a long moment, her expression unreadable. She glanced at Elias, a silent communication passing between them. Finally, she nodded. “The terms are… acceptable. In principle. Alfie Blackwood’s official narrative will be concluded. A tragic accident. A disappearance at sea. The details can be arranged.” She gestured towards the main doors of the hall. “It’s time to go, Mr. Blackwood. The local authorities will be responding to the… cessation of the public disturbance soon. We need to be gone.”

Alfie took one last, long look around the vast, empty hall. This place had been the anchor of his world, its stories woven into the fabric of his own identity. Now, it was just a building, silent and hollowed out. He was looking at his own tomb. He felt a pang of loss so sharp and profound it almost brought him to his knees. He had won the war and lost everything that mattered. With a final, weary sigh, he turned his back on the silence and walked towards the two figures, the shard held tight in his hand.

He followed them out of the DDH and into the pre-dawn light. The world was stirring back to a confused, hungover life. People were rubbing their eyes, looking around in bewilderment, the memory of their private madness fading like a bizarre dream. In the distance, the first sirens began to wail. The black Land Rover was waiting, its engine purring softly. As Elias held the rear door open, a light drizzle began to fall, pattering on the vehicle’s roof. Alfie paused, holding his hand out, letting the drops fall onto his skin. It was just water. Cold and wet. The texture was gone. The salt of the Irish Sea and the metallic tang of the shipyard were no longer carried on every drop. It was just rain, cleansed of its story. Wiping his hand on his coat, Alfie Blackwood climbed into the darkness of the truck, leaving the ghost of himself behind in the quiet, falling rain.

The interior of the Land Rover was a clean, functional space devoid of stories. There was no scent of old coffee, no echo of past arguments, no lingering psychic residue of any kind. It was a sterile, mobile cage, humming with a quiet efficiency as it moved through the waking streets of Barrow. Alfie sat in the back, the shard a cold, dense weight in his hand, his other pocket holding the inert rivet and the spent shell casing—the birth, death, and last will of his old life. Through the tinted window, he watched his town drift by like a series of disconnected photographs. The Ship Inn, where he’d shared pints with men from the yard. The corner shop where he bought his milk. Salthouse Road, where Kevin Tiller had made his beautiful, useless art. Each landmark was now just a building, a facade stripped of the vibrant history he had once been able to read as easily as newsprint.

He tried, out of a morbid, self-punishing curiosity, to reach out with his senses. He focused on the old sandstone library as they passed, a place that should have been thrumming with a century of quiet contemplation and whispered secrets. He felt nothing. A faint, sterile hiss, like an untuned radio. The DDH had been the town’s heart, its great psychic amplifier, and in his desperate act of war, he had performed a lobotomy on his own home. The rain still fell, but it was just water now. The texture was gone. The world, his world, had been rendered two-dimensional, its rich tapestry of echoes unravelled into a flat, meaningless plane. The loss was a physical ache, a phantom limb he knew would haunt him for the rest of his days.

“Where are we going?” he asked, his voice cracking from disuse, the words sounding loud and clumsy in the hermetic quiet of the vehicle.

Kaelen, the woman, answered from the passenger seat without turning around. “South. To a secure facility for intake and processing.” Elias, at the wheel, remained silent, his knuckles white on the steering wheel, a monolith of contained disapproval.

The word ‘processing’ hung in the air like the smell of antiseptic. “I’m a consultant, not a side of beef,” Alfie retorted, the spark of defiance rekindling faintly. “My terms were clear. I am not a specimen to be catalogued.”

“Processing is not punitive,” Kaelen clarified, her tone patient, as if explaining a complex concept to a child. “It involves a full medical and psychological evaluation to assess the extent of your exposure. We need to establish a baseline for your abilities and determine the nature of your symbiotic relationship with the asset. We catalogue everything, Mr. Blackwood. It is how we know what we are fighting. You are now part of that catalogue. That is the price of the clean slate you requested.”

The cold, clinical language sent a shiver through him that had nothing to do with his damp clothes. Symbiotic relationship. Asset. Entropic entity. They had a taxonomy for the horrors that lurked in the dark. “And who are you?” he pushed. “The Directorate. What is that? The world’s most heavily armed librarians?”

For the first time, a hint of something other than pure function entered her voice. It wasn’t quite humour, but it was a close cousin. “That’s a surprisingly accurate assessment. Think of reality as a membrane. Fragile. Porous. Things like Malachi, things like the asset in your hand, are pressures that seek to tear it. We are the ones who patch the holes. We are the Directorate of Extranormal Containment. We maintain the barrier between the world you think you know and the one that would unmake it without a second thought.”

They left Barrow behind, the familiar silhouette of the DDH shrinking in the rearview mirror until it was gone. The Land Rover merged onto the M6, joining the morning flow of lorries and commuter traffic. Each car they passed was a bubble of blissful ignorance, its occupants worried about deadlines and traffic jams, their lives governed by rules that Alfie now knew were suggestions at best. He was an exile, travelling through a country that was no longer his. The specific, gritty soul of his hometown was replaced by the anonymous blur of motorway verges and service stations, each one as psychically blank as the last. He clutched the shard tighter, its profound nothingness the only familiar thing he had left.

An hour south of the Cumbrian border, Elias took an exit, following signs not for a town or city, but for an industrial park. They bypassed the gleaming modern warehouses and drove towards a forgotten corner of the estate, a cluster of dilapidated, MoD-style hangars from a bygone era. Elias pulled the Land Rover up to a large, windowless building of faded green corrugated metal, its roller door firmly shut. There were no signs, no logos, no indication of its purpose. It was a place designed to be ignored.

Elias cut the engine, and the ensuing silence was absolute. “End of the line,” he grunted, his first words since leaving Barrow. Kaelen turned in her seat, her gaze finally meeting Alfie’s. Her eyes were a pale, dispassionate grey, the eyes of a scientist observing a volatile chemical reaction. “Welcome to your new life, Mr. Blackwood,” she said, her voice devoid of any welcome at all. “This is where it begins. Please, step outside.”

Alfie stepped out into the damp, grey air, the drizzle clinging to his face. The large roller door of the hangar ground upwards with a smooth, well-oiled whine, revealing an interior that was a stark refutation of the building’s dilapidated exterior. The space within was not a dusty warehouse but a bleached, sterile environment, lit by panels of flat, unblinking fluorescent light that banished all shadows. The floor was a seamless expanse of polished grey resin, and the air smelled faintly of ozone and disinfectant. A series of modular, white-walled rooms were arranged around a central processing area, their doors flush with the walls, their windows made of dark, reflective glass. It was less a hangar and more a laboratory that had swallowed a prison block.

Kaelen walked ahead of him into the blindingly white space, her boots making no sound on the pristine floor. Elias followed, a silent, grim-faced sentinel at Alfie’s back, effectively herding him forward. The roller door slid shut behind them, the sound a heavy, final thud that sealed him off from the world he knew. He was in their space now, a place with no history, no echoes, no texture. It was a sensory desert, and the silence here was not the peaceful quiet of a sanctuary, but the dead, insulated quiet of a padded cell.

“First, we decontaminate,” Kaelen announced, stopping in the centre of the room. She gestured to an alcove where a plain, grey jumpsuit was laid out on a bench. “Your current attire is compromised. It carries residual energetic and biological traces from multiple contact events. You will remove it and seal it in the provided bag. You will then undergo a preliminary sonic and ultraviolet cleanse.”

Alfie clutched the collar of his worn peacoat. It was a pathetic gesture, but the coarse wool was one of the last familiar things he had. It smelled of the sea, of rain, of cheap whisky, of home. It was a garment woven from the threads of his old life. “It’s a coat,” he said, his voice flat.

“It’s an evidence bag,” Kaelen corrected without malice. “Everything you are carrying is. Protocol requires a full inventory.” She pointed to a stainless-steel tray on a nearby table. “Empty your pockets, Mr. Blackwood.”

Slowly, his movements stiff with cold and defiance, he complied. He placed the heavy, inert rivet on the tray first, its mundane shape a stark contrast to the fantastic journey it had taken. Then came the 9mm shell casing, a tiny brass monument to the cold professionalism of his new keepers. He saved the shard for last, keeping it cupped in his palm. He looked at the two pieces of metal on the tray. They were the Alpha and Omega of his story, the beginning and the end. Kevin Tiller’s accidental legacy and the calling card of the men who were now his employers.

“And the asset,” Kaelen prompted, her eyes fixed on his closed hand. She held up the lead-lined box.

“No,” Alfie said, the word simple and unadorned. “That was the deal. I keep this until I’m satisfied. I am a long way from satisfied.”

Elias took a half-step forward, his hand drifting towards his side, a clear and present threat. Kaelen raised a single finger, not even looking at him, and he froze. She turned her full attention back to Alfie, her expression one of mild, academic curiosity. “The agreement was that you would not be disarmed without your consent. However, an uncontained null-field emitter cannot be permitted within the facility’s primary sectors. It interferes with our diagnostic systems. So, we have a logistical impasse. You require your leverage; we require a stable working environment. I propose a compromise.” From a pouch on her belt, she produced a simple leather harness with a small, lead-lined pouch at its centre, just large enough for the shard. “It will remain on your person, under your control, but its field will be dampened. A gesture of trust.”

It was no gesture of trust; it was a leash. But it was a leash that allowed him to keep his teeth. After a long, silent moment, Alfie nodded curtly. He placed the shard into the pouch and watched as Kaelen fastened the heavy flap. He then buckled the harness over his borrowed overalls, the weight of the contained void a strange and chilling anchor against his chest. With that done, he had no more excuses. He retreated to the alcove, stripped off his beloved peacoat and the rest of his damp, filthy clothes, and sealed them in the biohazard bag. He stood for a moment, naked and exposed under the merciless lights, a pale, scarred man out of time, before pulling on the grey, synthetic jumpsuit. It was textureless, odourless, and utterly anonymous. He caught his reflection in the dark glass of an observation window: a gaunt, hollow-eyed stranger with a black pouch strapped to his chest. Alfie Blackwood was gone. This was his replacement.

Kaelen led him from the central area down a long, white corridor. Every ten feet, a camera observed them from a recessed dome in the ceiling. The silence was absolute, broken only by the faint hum of ventilation. She stopped before a door identical to all the others and pressed her thumb to a panel beside it. The door slid open with a soft hiss of air. “This is Lab Three,” she said. “Your preliminary evaluation will take place here. Please, go inside.”

The room beyond was not a laboratory filled with beakers and microscopes. It was a small, circular chamber, its walls a smooth, unbroken white. In the centre was a single chair, more akin to a dentist’s chair than a piece of furniture, surrounded by an array of gleaming, articulated metal arms tipped with scanners, lenses, and devices he couldn’t begin to identify. It was a place designed for disassembly, for the methodical and intrusive exploration of a subject. A single, large pane of one-way glass dominated the far wall. He knew, without a doubt, that Elias was standing on the other side. This was not a consultation. This was an interrogation, conducted not with questions, but with scalpels of light and energy. The violation he was about to face was of a different order than Malachi’s, but no less absolute. It was the cold, sterile, and passionless violation of the cataloguer, and it felt, in that moment, infinitely more terrifying.

## Chapter 9

He stood before the chair, a condemned man surveying the gallows. It was a throne of violation, its gleaming arms and polished surfaces designed not for comfort but for access. This was the antithesis of everything he was. His power came from the grit and grime of history, from the stories embedded in rust and decay. This place, this chair, was a shrine to the sterile and the new, a temple built to strip away all context, all story, until only raw, quantifiable data remained. The silence was the most oppressive part. It was a manufactured silence, a sensory deprivation chamber designed to make him the loudest thing in the room, his every psychic twitch a scream in the quiet. He felt flayed, his defences torn away, leaving him psychically naked under the cold, unblinking gaze of the machine.

“Please be seated, Mr. Blackwood,” Kaelen’s voice said, issuing from a hidden speaker. It was disembodied, clinical, the voice of a goddess who ruled this particular white-walled hell. He walked to the chair, each step a capitulation, and sat down. The material was cold and unyielding against the thin fabric of his jumpsuit. With a series of soft, pneumatic hisses, padded restraints slid into place over his wrists, ankles, and forehead. They were not brutal, not painfully tight, but their gentle, implacable firmness was a more profound statement of his powerlessness than any iron shackle. The lights in the room dimmed slightly, and the array of articulated arms began to move, their lenses and scanners swivelling to focus on him with a silent, insectile precision.

The scan began not with a jolt, but with a creeping sense of invasion. A low-frequency hum resonated through the chair, a vibration tuned to the very marrow of his bones, seeming to seek the unique frequency of his soul. Beams of pale blue and crimson light played across his body, passing through his skin without heat, their purpose not to illuminate but to catalogue. He felt a disorienting pressure build behind his eyes, a non-physical probing that sought to map the esoteric pathways of his mind, to trace the very architecture of his gift. He reacted with the only defence he had left. He retreated. He pulled his consciousness inward, shrinking away from the intrusive sensors, building a wall of pure, stubborn negation around the core of his being. He could not stop them from scanning the house, but he could refuse to answer the door.

Kaelen’s voice returned, laced with a new thread of clinical impatience. “Subject is demonstrating non-cooperative psychic shielding. The field is amorphous and highly resistant. Initiate stimulus protocol Delta-Seven. We need a reactive baseline.” Suddenly, the formless pressure in his mind was replaced by something sharp, angular, and utterly alien. It was not a memory or an emotion, but a pure concept, a psychic data-stream forced into his consciousness. It felt of crystalline lattices, of mathematics given form, of a cold, geometric intelligence that had never known the warmth of blood or the messiness of a soul. It was the echo of a thing that had never lived in a way he could understand, and its touch was a nauseating violation, a glimpse into the Directorate’s library of horrors.

The alien stimulus was a spike driven into his carefully constructed wall of silence. He recoiled violently, not physically, but psychically, a silent scream of revulsion echoing in the confines of his own mind. This was not the familiar, messy humanity he was used to; this was a glimpse of the cold, unfeeling cosmos that the Directorate stood guard against. Cornered and desperate, he lashed out, not with the grand, theatrical power he had wielded in the DDH, but with the oldest and most fundamental part of his gift. He reached for the feeling of iron, the familiar, grounding presence of metal. He ignored the sterile, modern alloys of the lab and focused on the deep, ancestral memory of iron itself—its birth in fire, its patient surrender to rust, its inherent, flawed nature. He found a single, insignificant servo in the gleaming arm nearest his head, and he whispered to it. He did not command it to break. He simply reminded it of its own mortality, of the inevitable decay that was its birthright.

For a fraction of a second, the universe listened. The servo, a marvel of modern engineering designed for a hundred thousand hours of flawless operation, stuttered. A single, microscopic gear tooth, suddenly mindful of its own potential for metal fatigue, skipped its rhythm. The arm’s impossibly smooth motion was broken by an almost imperceptible hiccup, a twitch so small it was less a malfunction and more a moment of mechanical doubt. The diagnostic systems must have shrieked. The humming ceased instantly. The lights returned to their full, merciless brightness. The articulated arms froze, then retracted smoothly into the walls. The silence rushed back in, but this time, it was a silence filled with a question.

The restraints hissed and slid away. “Evaluation concluded,” Kaelen’s voice stated, the words flat and uninflected, yet somehow different. The door to the chamber slid open. Alfie sat there for a long moment, a profound, soul-deep tremor running through him. He had not won, not in any meaningful sense. But he had answered their force with a quiet, stubborn refusal they could not ignore. He had spoken to their machine in a language of decay it was not supposed to understand. He had proven he was not just data to be collected; he was a variable that could disrupt the equation. Pushing himself up on unsteady legs, he walked out of the white room, his point made.

Elias was waiting for him, his face an unreadable mask of granite. He simply jerked his head, a silent command to follow, and led Alfie down another identical white corridor. Alfie expected a cell, a holding pen. But the door Elias opened led to a small, spartan room containing a single bed made up with crisp grey sheets, a simple metal desk and chair, and a sealed food tray resting on the desk. It was a prison, but it was a prison with the basic dignities of a room. The door slid shut behind him, and he was alone. There was no lock he could hear, but he knew he was as secure as if he were at the bottom of a mine shaft.

He ignored the food, his stomach a tight knot of exhaustion and dread. A thin data slate lay beside the tray. He picked it up, its surface cool and smooth. With a flick of his thumb, the screen came to life, displaying a single webpage, cached from the outside world. It was an article from the North-West Evening Mail. The headline read: “Local Man Feared Lost at Sea After Debris Found Near Walney.” Beneath it was a photograph of him from years ago, grainy and unfamiliar, taken at a pub quiz. He read the short, sterile paragraphs detailing the discovery of a peacoat and personal effects, the suspension of the search, the presumption of his death. It was his official obituary. He was a ghost now, his life neatly concluded and filed away. Alfie switched off the screen, plunging the room into the soft, ambient light. He sat heavily on the edge of the hard bed, the cold, lead-lined weight of the shard pouch a constant, pressing reminder against his chest. His first day in his new life was over, and all it had cost him was everything.

He sat on the edge of the hard bed for a time that had no measure, the only sound the whisper of the ventilation system, a sterile breath that was the polar opposite of the salt-laced wind he had known his entire life. The data slate lay dark beside him, his own death certificate contained in its memory. He was a ghost, but not a restless one. He was simply… erased. The thought should have been terrifying, but he was too profoundly weary for terror. It was just a fact, as solid and unchangeable as the white walls of his cell. He reached for the food tray, his movements slow and automatic. He peeled back the plastic film. Inside was a grey, protein paste, a portion of steamed, unnaturally green vegetables, and a dense, biscuit-like rectangle of carbohydrates. It smelled of nothing. He took a bite of the paste. It tasted of nutrients, of sustenance, of utter, soul-crushing absence. It was the perfect meal for his new life. He ate mechanically, not because he was hungry, but because his body was a machine that required fuel, and he was its reluctant operator.

When he had finished, he pushed the tray aside and drew his knees up to his chest, wrapping his arms around them. The lead-lined pouch containing the shard was a cold, heavy weight against his sternum. In the profound silence of the room, a silence that was a sensory void, the shard’s own perfect nullity felt almost companionable. It was the one thing in this place that was honest. The walls pretended to be solid, the food pretended to be sustenance, the Directorate pretended to be offering him a life. The shard made no such pretences. It was a hole, and it did not apologize for it. He found a strange solace in its integrity. It was the only landmark he had left in a world that had been wiped clean of all distinguishing features. He was no longer Alfie Blackwood, the warlock of Barrow. He was the man with the hole in his chest, a custodian of nothing.

The hiss of the door sliding open broke his reverie. Kaelen stood in the doorway, holding a data slate of her own. She did not enter fully but stood on the threshold, a clear demarcation between her space and his. Her grey eyes swept over the room, noting the empty food tray, his posture, the dark slate on the desk. She was a scientist observing a specimen in its new, controlled habitat. She registered his compliance, his consumption of the provided nutrients, and filed it away as a data point.

“Your bio-signs are stabilizing,” she announced, her voice as flat and devoid of texture as the food he had just eaten. “The preliminary evaluation yielded some… anomalous readings. Your ability to influence ferrous materials without a significant expenditure of energy is a deviation from known psychometric models. The effect on the servo was not a kinetic push. It was more akin to a semantic suggestion. You told it what it was, and it listened. This is new.”

“I’m full of surprises,” Alfie mumbled, his voice a dry rasp. He did not look at her, keeping his gaze fixed on the opposite white wall.

“That is why you are valuable,” she replied, ignoring his sarcasm. “And as our newest, and most… unique consultant, your first consultation is now required. Your cooperation in Lab Three, while grudging, confirmed your utility. Now it is time to apply it.” She tapped her data slate, and the screen on his desk lit up, displaying a rotating, three-dimensional image of a new object. It was a twisted knot of metal, about the size of a human heart. It was clearly not man-made. The metal was a dark, iridescent bronze, and it was fused in places with a crystalline material that pulsed with a faint, sickly purple light. It looked diseased, a piece of biomechanical viscera ripped from some impossible creature.

“Item 734,” Kaelen stated. “Recovered from a downed satellite over the Siberian tundra three years ago. It emits a low-level psychic broadcast on a repeating loop. The content of the broadcast induces paranoia, obsessive-compulsive behaviour, and eventually, catatonic schizophrenia in all sentient life within a ten-meter radius. All attempts to read its origin or purpose via conventional psychic or technological means have failed. The broadcast is a psychic signal, but it has no recognizable author or emotional content. It is a signal without a story. We have shielded it, of course, but we have never understood it. You, Mr. Blackwood, are a new variable. You read stories where others cannot. We want to know what story this object is telling.”

Alfie finally looked at her, a cold dread seeping into the marrow of his bones. This was his new job. Not to find lost things or coax secrets from old iron, but to be the Directorate’s canary, sent down the darkest, most poisonous mines of reality to see if he would sing or die. This was not a consultation; it was a vivisection. They would expose him to these horrors, these broken pieces of other worlds, and record how he broke. He thought of Kevin Tiller, dead on his workshop floor, his final thought a simple, heartbreaking *Why?* Alfie was beginning to understand that in this new world, ‘why’ was a luxury, a question that had been replaced by a much simpler one: ‘what?’

“And if I say no?” he asked, his voice quiet.

“Then you will remain in this room, and we will continue with less… collaborative forms of evaluation,” Kaelen replied, the threat delivered with the detached calm of a doctor prescribing an unpleasant but necessary treatment. “Your status as a consultant is contingent upon you consulting. The choice, as always, is yours.” She turned to leave. “Lab Three. In five minutes.”

The door hissed shut, leaving him once more in the profound, deadening silence. He looked at the image of the pulsating, diseased object on the screen. It was an invitation to madness, a doorway to a new kind of horror. But it was also a door out of this white room. He pushed himself off the bed. He was no longer the quiet reader of Barrow’s history. He was an asset, a tool. And a tool, he thought with a grim finality, was meant to be used. He would go to their lab. He would touch their monster. He would read its terrible story. But he would read it for himself, another secret to be held close, another piece of leverage in the long, quiet war he was now fighting for the tattered remnants of his own soul.

### Chapter 10

The five minutes passed in a silence so profound it felt like a countdown to an execution. The door to his cell slid open with a soft hiss, and Elias stood there, his presence as solid and unyielding as a block of granite. He didn’t speak, merely jerked his head in a silent command. In its place, a slender, black metal pedestal rose from the centre of the floor. Upon it, resting under a shimmering, faintly visible containment field, was Item 734. He could feel it trying to find purchase in his mind, searching for loose threads of memory or emotion to pull. His old method of passive listening would be suicide here; it would be like opening his front door in the middle of a hurricane. He needed a new defence. He reached for the memory of the null-shard, not its power, but its nature. The feeling of absolute, perfect silence. The absence of story. He had to translate the apocalypse into a manageable crisis. “It’s a weapon,” he managed to rasp, his voice raw. “A trap. It’s not sentient… it’s a mindless, psychic claymore. An area-denial device. The broadcast is designed to overload the cognitive functions of any organic mind in its vicinity, to induce catastrophic system failure. It’s a booby trap, left over from a war I can’t see.” It was the truth, but it was the truth from an altitude of ten thousand feet, concealing the horrifying, granular reality of its purpose.

Through the observation window, he saw Kaelen confer with Elias. His report seemed to satisfy them. A "psychic claymore" was a known quantity, a horror they could label and file. He had given them a neat, tidy box for their unutterable horror. Elias entered the lab, his face impassive, and gestured for Alfie to come. The consultation was over. He had performed his function. He was led back to his cell, the walk a blur of pain and disorientation. The door hissed shut, and he collapsed onto the bed, the white room spinning around him. He closed his eyes, but there was no darkness, no peace. There was only the faint, persistent, and terrifying flicker of a string of purple, geometric code, a cancerous seed of an alien world now planted in the silent, empty garden of his mind. He had survived his first day as a consultant. He now had a new and terrible secret, a poison he could not share, and a chilling certainty that the quiet war for his soul had just acquired a new, and deeply personal, front.

### Chapter 10

The silence in the room was a physical weight, a thick blanket that smothered thought. But it could not smother the flicker. Alfie lay on the hard cot, his eyes squeezed shut, but the image was burned onto the inside of his eyelids, a persistent and horrifying afterimage. The string of glowing purple geometry pulsed in time with his own frantic heartbeat, a parasitic tattoo on his soul. It was not a memory; it was an active process. He could feel it, a tiny, cold engine of alien logic, testing the walls of his consciousness, seeking to interface with his own thoughts, to translate his memories and emotions into its own sterile, mathematical language. It was a single sentence from a book that could unwrite the universe, and he had become the page it was written on.

He pushed himself into a sitting position, a wave of dizziness and nausea washing over him. The metallic taste of blood was still thick in his mouth. He tried to erect the psychic shields he had used for years to keep the noisy echoes of the world at bay, a familiar fortress of will and quiet intention. It was utterly useless. The purple code did not try to breach his walls; it was already inside them. It operated on a level beneath thought, beneath emotion. It was a fundamental instruction, and his mind, his very soul, was the hardware it was running on. Fighting it with his old methods was like trying to stop a flood with a fishing net. The code wasn't an invading army; it was a subtle change in the laws of physics inside his own head.

A cold, desperate panic began to thread its way through the fog of his exhaustion. He was contaminated. Compromised. He was a walking time bomb, a carrier for a plague that could rewrite reality, and no one knew but him. His lie to Kaelen had been a brilliant act of self-preservation, but it had also been a death sentence. He had isolated himself completely, cutting off any hope of help from the very people who might understand the nature of the threat. He had traded a quick, clean death by a bullet for a slow, agonizing dissolution into something other. He fumbled at the harness on his chest, his fingers clumsy and numb. He tore at the flap of the lead-lined pouch, the simple act requiring an immense effort of will. His hand closed around the shard.

The relief was instantaneous and absolute. The moment his skin touched the shard's inert surface, the flickering purple geometry in his mind dimmed. The maddening, silent hum of its alien logic faded, suppressed by the shard's profound and perfect nothingness. It was like plunging a screaming radio into the deep ocean. The code wasn't gone—he could still sense it, a faint, frustrated presence huddled in a corner of his mind, walled off by the encroaching void of the shard—but it was silenced. He gasped, taking a deep, shuddering breath, the first clean breath he had taken since touching the artifact. The silence in the room was no longer oppressive; it was a sanctuary he had carved out for himself. The shard was no longer just leverage. It was his antidote. His anchor. The only thing keeping him himself.

He held the shard in his lap, a cold stone of salvation, and the terrible irony of his situation settled upon him. He was a prisoner of the Directorate, and they were his only protection from the outside world. He was a host to a psychic virus, and his only protection from it was the very object that had led him into this mess. He was a jailer holding the key to his own cage, a key that was also a poison, and his only freedom was a deeper, more profound imprisonment. He was trapped in a nesting doll of his own making, and at the very centre, a single, terrifying question began to form: what happened when the Directorate decided they wanted their key back for good?

The door hissed open, and Kaelen entered. This time, she came all the way into the room, her presence a sharp, clinical intrusion into his fragile peace. She held a data slate, but her focus was entirely on him. Her gaze dropped to the shard in his lap, then rose to meet his eyes. Her expression was, for the first time, not entirely neutral. There was a flicker of intense, scientific curiosity, the look of a biologist who has just seen a microbe perform a wholly unexpected trick. "Your neural activity," she began, her voice a precise, clipped monotone, "spiked to catastrophic levels upon your return to this room. Then, approximately ninety seconds ago, it stabilized to a level of calm that is statistically improbable for a subject in your circumstances. You have self-medicated. You are actively using the asset's null-field to suppress your own psychic trauma. That is… remarkable."

"I'm a remarkable man," Alfie said, his voice flat. He did not bother to hide the shard. It was better she believed it was a tool for his comfort rather than a weapon against an infection she knew nothing about. Let her think he was using it as a psychic crutch. It was a far safer explanation than the truth.

"Your deception regarding Item 734 has been logged and accepted," she continued, either ignoring or filing away his response. "Your designation of the object as a 'psychic claymore' fits within established parameters for xenocidal ordinance. You have proven your utility. As such, the Directorate has seen fit to grant you access to Level-Two amenities. Your 'consultations' have earned you a degree of trust." She offered him her data slate. On the screen was a schematic of a new room. It was larger than his cell, dominated by a heavy, metallic workbench and lined with shelves. On the shelves were dozens of objects, all sealed in clear, evidence-style containers. An old, rusted sextant. A tarnished silver locket. A child's spinning top made of pewter. They were pieces of his world, pieces of history.

"This is Workshop Seven," Kaelen explained. "All items within have been psychically sterilized. Their stories have been erased. They are blank slates. Your unique ability to… 'suggest' a state of being to ferrous materials is of great interest to us. We wish to observe it under controlled conditions. This workshop is your new cage, Mr. Blackwood. But it is a cage where you will be allowed to practice your craft. Consider it your reward. You will be escorted there in one hour." She took the slate back, turned, and left, the door hissing shut behind her. Alfie stared at the blank white wall, the silence rushing back in. A reward. A workshop full of dead things. They were going to give him a room full of corpses and ask him to teach them how to dance, all so they could learn how to build better weapons. And he knew, with a sinking, cold certainty, that he would go. He would go, because a cage with tools was better than a cage without, and he had a cancer in his soul that he desperately needed to learn how to cut out.
